description: This restaurant is conveniently located in the JW Marriott in San Francisco. The menu is brief but had enough variety to find something you would enjoy. We were staying in the hotel so we enjoyed both dinner and breakfast at this restaurant . The restaurant staff were all very friendly. We had plans in the evening and service was quick , breakfast was leisurely and we were not rushed. The menu is pricey but the portions are big. The food was great. My favorite was the Brussels sprouts appetizer. After an evening out , I passed by the restaurant going back to room and the waitress remembered my name and wished me a pleasant evening , nice touch!!
author: Michelle D.

description:
REVIEWER #189

Well dang! Did I feel fancy up in this G-thang! 

Level III has it goin' on! Everything from the sexy JW Marriott hotel, to the friendly staff members, oh-let's not forget about the sexy chandeliers once you step out the 3rd floor! Whoo! At least come here to check out the décor and ambiance-you will be just as amazed as I was! 

Level III is located in beautiful San Francisco's Union Square-JW Marriott hotel. The restaurant is a little pricey then the norm, but it's because you are paying for the location (nothing in D/T Union Square is cheap!). 

The bar area is a great place to sit and relax (chat with the bartenders). They also have seating areas in the restaurant and areas to sit around the restaurant that consist of outlets to charge your electronics (sweet)! Some friends and I decided to get together here to enjoy a couple drinks and I was shocked at how cute this place was! The hotel itself is gorgeous and impressive, but the bar is a MUST! 

I hear there burgers here are delicious, wait-lemme not forget about their well-known Mac and Cheese!! I'm still wondering why I didn't order that dish! However, I ordered the Truffle Fries and dived right into a Lemon Drop and they both did not disappoint. I appreciated that the menu was short and simple, but at the same time offered a little bit of everything you want. 
Happy hour!! Don't we all love happy hour deals? Well, Level III has half price off their 3 signature cocktails, red and white wine. Hours are from 4PM-7PM Monday-Friday! 

Did I mention they have a wonder wine list! Yess, honey! The wine itself is enough for me to keep coming back. During the weekends, they offer a wonderful l JW Buffet which consists of a lovely health y breakfast and a create-your-own omelet from 6:30AM-11AM. Lunch and Dinner is served from 11AM-11PM.
author: Porsche C.

description:
Wow: had room service at JW Marriott, and this meal was the best part of my stay.
From the gem chop salad  with impeccably sliced avocados , to the juicy steak frites, to the delicious creme brûlée with the perfect amount of crispy sugar on top, everything was prepared perfectly!
author: Allie C.

description: Our waitress was not very attentive and did not know the menu or what was available. The manager seemed to recognize this and came over to get us drinks after we sat for 5 minutes without drinks. The food was pretty good. My husbands steak and eggs was very good. I would say it's a good place to eat if you are staying in the hotel, but I would not travel out of the way to go there. FYI- The restaurant is open to the lobby of the Marriott. The lobby is pretty.
author: Amber S.

description: Since it's inside the JW I already expected nothing but the best. Expectations definitely met. Good food. Great service. Couldn't ask for more
author: Michelle T.

description: Very very good!! We came in late and STILL received excellent service. Never felt rushed. I was pleasantly surprised at the creative twist the chef placed on common meals. The bread they bring before your meal was delicious. I really enjoyed the open atmosphere of the bar area and the intimacy of the restaurant itself. If this is a romantic dinner you can snug up in a corner booth. Also had breakfast and it was equally great. Prices typical of San Fran downtown area. See my pics :)
author: Jenna M.

description: I want to say the host Scott and his waiting staff are absolutely amazing. Best eggs Benedict I've had in a long long time. I give the dining experience 5*. Can't thank Scott enough.
author: Robert M.

description:
Unfortunately, didn't even order. Menu was filthy and had food on it when it was brought to us. Staff didn't even appear aware of very much. 

I don't like giving a poor review especially when we didn't make it to ordering. The food maybe alright as well as the staff but, we were turned off before even making it that far.
author: J B.

description:
Well the Kettle one lemon drops are amazing.  Not cheap, but damn good.  

The trio of desserts is mediocre at best, but when you need sugar and don't want to leave the comfort of your your hotel, it'll do.

The table service is pretty bad...one woman for the entire lobby, but the service at the bar was great, as long as you don't mind waiting for your order.
author: Lucky S.

description: This was a pleasant surprise, we spent a weekend at the jw marriot in union square and decided one night to try the hotels restaurant that being level 3. The food was amazing and the service even better. Make sure Samia is working because she was just the best! I wouldn't say its the cheapest meal around but for the area and the quality of food I definitely felt I had gotten a good value. No matter how full you get you MUST try the creme Brule it just may be the best thing I have ever eaten.
author: Ryan B.

description:
My wife, 3 year old son, and coworkers had dinner here tonight.  The food was excellent and the service was great, which is enough to bring us back, but a personal gesture by the hostess set this experience apart.  The hostess noted that my son likes trains and gave him a cable car toy to keep.  

The atmosphere at the restaurant is classy, a little more so than I usually see at hotel restaurants.  I ordered the artisan grilled cheese, my wife ordered the turkey club, my coworkers ordered the filet mignon and grass-fed burger.  We all enjoyed our food and the toasted marshmallow/peanut butter/banana dessert that came after.  Again, the food and service was enough to bring us back, the personal touch is what we've come to expect from Marriott.
author: Jonathan K.

description: We went in on the 4th of July holiday around 6 and the place was dead. I was a little worried based on that and the reviews but the food and service was great. The server was very warm, friendly, knowledge of the menu and accommodating. Might be considered pricy but relative to the area. Great kids menu with different options. I would definitely recommend it!
author: Katie H.

description: I was not a fan. Had some service issues with the staff. So not impressed at at. Will not be coming back. To much attitude from them.
author: Joe M.

description:
My family and I had a great experience here. We told them that we had a flight to catch and they were very accommodating and brought out our food as soon as each plate was made. They also brought out a small Greek yogurt dish as a complimentary appetizer before our food came out. Every plate I tried was fresh and tasty. I recommend the following lunch items: brussel sprouts, kale salad, pumpkin ravioli. 
We had made reservations but the restaurant was quiet and empty. Only one thing is that we couldn't find our waiter in sight to order our food and had to get up and find him. I found this odd since we were one of the few parties at the restaurant.
author: Monica S.

description: Went here for Christmas pre fixe menu and everything was tasty but the star of the show was the Marrow crusted short Rib! It was delicious! Best I've eaten ever. My family had a great dinner, the wait staff was attentive and the wine selection was nice. Will definitely come back next time I'm in San Francisco!
author: Kamila P.

description:
I was staying at the JW Marriott and after a long day of sightseeing, I decided to have a late lunch and a cocktail. I sat down at the end of the bar because I just wanted to relax and there was a crowd near the middle. I ordered a drink with tequila, grapefruit, and maraschino liqueur. Unfortunately for me, there were no prices listed and shame, shame I should have known better. I drank 2 and they were $14 a pop. 

I got the fish tacos which were certainly not an entrée portion. There were three tacos. They had seasoned fish, onions, and crème fraiche in corn tortillas. They came with a side of guacamole and salsa. They were pretty good but nothing spectacular, however they set me back another $20. So all in all, drinks, food, mandatory tax, and tip, it cost me over $60 to have lunch. It was most certainly not worth $60.
author: Megan K.

description:
Not very bad at all! We came to get dinner before watching wicked (amazing show) and I'm glad we came early. We arrived around 5:30 to a relatively empty restaurant (alarming at first) and got settled in. Here's the breakdown: 

-cheese tray: omg get it! Delicious mix of cheese, breads, fruit, crackers, etc
-roasted chicken dish: it was just ok, chicken could've used more flavor and risotto that came with it was just kind of whatever. 
- side dishes: asparagus was very good, but the Mac and cheese was disappointing. After a few bites it tasted similar to something from a freezer. The purple potatoes.. Delicious! Probably one of the best dishes we ordered. Definitely get it! 
- dessert: we ordered the sampler which was 3 small desserts and it was just the right size; however, the desserts themselves were just ok. 

The service was very good, our server was helpful and attentive. The restaurant itself is nicely setup and offers a good view of the city. Definitely recommended if you're looking for a nice dinner in SF!
author: S. P.

description:
Well.....if you've read the reviews from Hannah C. and Bobby L. my review of Level III will pretty much be very similar since I was part of that lunch group.  We were looking for a restaurant to have for lunch during Dine About Town and I decided to go with Level III since I was really impressed with their food when they held a Yelp Elite Event there a few weeks earlier.

We were so excited because we read on their DAT menu that they would have Ribeye Steak there for $17.95.  BUT, when the waiter came to take our order, the first thing he tells us is that "We don't have Ribeye, only NY Steak.  It's Better.  You'll like it."  They pulled the old 'Bait and Switch' tactic on us!!!  So yeah, we settled for the NY Steak since the waiter claims "It's Better" than Ribeye.  Uh huh, yeah sure.

1st course - Endive Salad
(http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/qxQ2OSOZgruD0q2QI2WeKA?select=kZJ0nMT9rjS2gYS3rVmLrw)
While it looks pretty, I didn't really care too much for this salad.  Probably because I was still feeling bitter that they didn't have any Ribeye.

Main Course - Ribeye....Oops, I meant NY Steak and Garlic Fries
(http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/qxQ2OSOZgruD0q2QI2WeKA?select=e9K3qyq8oJB0ozHv4snIFQ)
The NY Steak wasn't too bad.  It was cooked fine and medium rare as I requested.  But it definitely wasn't "Better" than a Ribeye steak.  And the Garlic Fries were just okay.

The real kicker was what happened with Hannah C.'s order.  We both ordered our steaks medium rare, yet when they brought them out, mine was fine, but her's was well done to a crisp.  How the cook messed that up is a mystery.  When we told the waiter about it, he said that the "order confused the cook" which is didn't make sense since we both ordered our steaks medium rare.  Well, eventually they fired up another steak for Hannah and it was medium rare.

To shed some light, despite all the mishaps, we kind of found this dining experience to be indirectly entertaining.  We probably won't dine here again for DAT.  If you do consider going here for Dine About Town, take extreme caution as you'll probably get something different than what's advertised.
author: Rodney H.

description:
Pulled into the whole holiday spirit, we decided to hit up the hotel bar, get a little festive and order a nice little strong cocktail. As I ordered a Maker's Mark Manhattan from the bartender he asked me "Sweet" or "Spicy"?

Ummm, always spicy. He adds some Ancho Chile powder to my Manhattan and slips me the bill - $16. One drink, sixteen dollars? Wow, it was good but not that good. I've had better Manhattans with better bourbon than that. 

Although the cocktail was delicious, it really didn't make me want to stick around for another one. Off to another place instead.
author: Rebekah T.

description:
"The quality of food is in inverse proportion to a dining room's altitude, especially atop bank and hotel buildings (airplanes are an extreme example)."-Bryan Miller

Maybe Bryan Millers words are true because all the Marriott's/Ritz Carlton lounges I've been going to, are on the ground floor or as in the case of Level III, it's located on (this makes sense right?) the third floor.  Also the higher up a dining room's altitude, the higher the prices get.

As of late, I've ended up at Marriott hotels and it's partner company Ritz Carlton, eating at their restaurants/lounges.  And I'm realizing these hotels have a really nice chic atmosphere, good food, service, and comparatively reasonable prices.  

Arriving on the third floor via Marriott's cool elevators, I loved how the bar area looked.   Contemporary all white upholstered benches, stools, tables laid out nice for chillaxin, and comfortable booth areas overlooking the City.

The menu looked great with entrees like filet mignon, oysters, sliders, sea bass, and Mac & Cheese.  I ordered a couple beers at the bar and socialized with my friends.

Since I came during a Yelp event I was able to sample a few items from the menu:

Kobe Beef Sliders:  very tasty, cooked to medium, with fresh toasted slider buns.  No better social finger food than sliders except maybe buffalo wings..

Mac & Cheese:  it was ok, it's hard with all the competition out there making this cherished comfort food.

I also had good desserts and of course the cause and solution to all of mankind's problems: alcohol.

So in my Level 3 voice... Here's a clip of my Level 6 voice:  
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=snmUrzdMRFQ&feature=youtube_gdata_player

Level III lounge is a great place to socialize even if you aren't staying at the Marriott.  BTW, you DON'T want to see me go to 10!!!
author: Michael L.

description:
Had an amazing time for brunch here. The elevator was a but confusing, but given the name...everything panned out (you'll get it when you go)

Located inside JW Marriott on he 3rd Floor. 

Had the most amazing table by the window on a sunny bright day. Donna was our server and she was very attentive.  

Ordered the Salmon with roasted vegetables. Slow cooked and MR for the win! 

There was a conference going on , but they were able to put up set sounds walls to keep the setting still intimate. 

The decor and ambiance alone was enough for me to come back. This time for a night cap.
author: David D.

description:
Believe the reviews about the Mac and cheese. So true! On par for a hotel's signature eatery , very pricey and high brow service. However the food was fab and the drinks did not disappoint. Über bright in the dinning area. 

Faves: lobster mac and cheese, crispy pork belly
author: Christina L.

description:
We enjoyed happy hour here. They have a couple of flat screen TVs for sports. Our server was quick to serve us and very friendly but professional. We enjoyed two apps- edamame with sesame and togarashi as well as pita with hummus and eggplant. Both were very nice. Especially liked the seasonings on the edamame!  Yum. 
They had a decent selection of happy hr drinks, though after the server let us taste the house Chardonnay we went with a non-happy hr wine. 
Enjoyed our time here!
author: Dale H.

description: Don't go to the @JPMarriott in #SF. They charged me $80 to reserve a table because of the JP Morgan Healthcare Conference - just for drinks!
author: David L.

description: Four-course prix fixe dinner was beautifully prepared, deliciously consumed, and elegantly served. Some memorable notes were that they waived the corkage fee to accommodate the four vintages we thoughtfully selected for the occasion, and the parking too (!). Recommendation for patrons is to share with your wait staff-they work hard to keep your drinks flowing and your conversations going. Also, take a moment to appreciate what you have and celebrate your life as you have lived it. Thank you Level 3!
author: utterly i.

description: Came here for a quick bite the other day and ordered fish tacos. The fish was pan-seared halibut. There were three tacos in the order, with generous portions of halibut.
author: christina diem p.

description:
Where do I begin.... false advertisement (NO RIBEYE on DAT menu) or a clueless waiter with an attitude. 

Quite an interesting experience and was very much service related.

We were super excited to try the ribeye on the Dine About Town lunch menu.  When it came time to order, the waiter said no ribeye but there's NY steak and "New York steak is better than ribeye".  Are you for real???  **This just cracked us up.   

Disappointed and caught off guard, a friend took an extra minute to decide on the order.  During this time, the waiter impatiently said "There really aren't many choices on the menu to decide.  Either one or the other".  MMMM ATTITUDE!!!

So let's talk food.  Among the 3 of us, we were able to sample all choices from the menu:  seafood chowder, endive watercress salad, pan roasted chicken breast, and the infamous "better-than-ribeye" NY steak. 

The endive salad with julienne fuji apple, candied walnuts, and blue cheese was refreshing (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/qxQ2OSOZgruD0q2QI2WeKA?select=F__a4h37qLFJobBlX5rMcw). 

The seafood chowders with clams, scallops, and crab meat also had chunks of potatoes and carrots.  It was creamy and pretty good.  (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/qxQ2OSOZgruD0q2QI2WeKA?select=g2vak9m0xNU9Wml3BPtsoQ).  

The chicken breast with maitake mushroom & roasted tomato risotto. Chicken was ok but the risotto wasn't good. It tasted like canned tomatoes were added.   (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/qxQ2OSOZgruD0q2QI2WeKA?select=sDPDav85ceJ9jIASfSfEAg) 

Back to the waiter.  Two of us ordered medium rare steaks but I happened to be the unlucky person to send back the well done steak and wilted fries.  When I told the waiter, he accused my friend for having mistakenly eaten my steak.  He also came back to tell me that the chef was confused if I wanted my steak more or less cooked. Haha really?  Can we say confusion!!!  He did return later with a medium rare steak.  The fries were definitely better when they were crispy.  (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/qxQ2OSOZgruD0q2QI2WeKA?select=9sub3qrAT_w7r-ueS-1_iQ)

Our waiter was pretty clueless.  He never stop by to check if we needed anything.  Keep in mind the restaurant wasn't busy. He also didn't know how to split the bill on 2 separate credit cards and that we would have to wait for him to figure it out. Afraid of having to wait for 30 minutes, we put the entire bill onto one card.  Sigh.
author: Hannah C.

description:
This place is unforgettable!  

Highlights include...

-Nice modern decor and ambiance.

-Waiter telling us that the ribeye (featured on the DAT lunch menu) is not available and that NY steak is better anyways.  

-Spotty service with a hint of attitude.  Our waiter and the chef were "confused?" (we know what medium rare is!)

-The Seafood Chowder....best part of my entire meal.  I've had better Risotto.  Chicken was okay, like all other chicken dishes served at hotel receptions.  Maitake mushrooms...I wish I had more.  

-GARLIC FRIES took my attention away from the NY steak.  And no Mr. waiter, It wasn't better than any ribeye I've had.  

--------------------------------------------------------

Solid 2 stars.  Unfortunately, my Dine About Town experience here wasn't a very positive one.
author: Bobby L.

description: Since we were staying at the Marriott and the Giants game was on (they had not lost the season  yet) we decided to have cocktails and food at the Level III bar.  First off, the bartender was so unhappy working, while a team "he does not like" is playing on the TV made it quite uncomfortable for the guests enjoying the game.  Since the game went into 13 innings and the bar closed at 11, he turned off all the lights and left us in the dark to watch the game and finish our drinks.  Talk about RUDE. We had the cheese plate, which was actually ok.  But the service made the experience unpleasant.  Won't be back - overpriced as well
author: Deb U.

description:
I've tried this place at least 3 times.  The name suits this place because the food deserves a level 3 out of 5.  Nothing is special here and everything is expensive because it is at the JW Marriott.  I can't remember much from my meals except that it wasn't memorable.

Service is friendly and helpful.  The decor and ambiance is well lit and comfortable with booths and tables.  Parking can be tough on the street unless you use valet service at the hotel or want to pay for a local garage.
author: Jenny L.

description:
SF's Dine About Town really serves two purposes:

1) To be able to sample a prix fixed menu at nice restaurants for an affordable price in the hopes of coming back

2) To be able to sample a prix fixed menu at nice restaurants for an affordable price so that you wouldn't come back and spend more on the regular menu

Unfortunately, Level III falls into category 2.

I'll admit, the decor can be interpreted as maybe artistic, stylish even, but that novelty soon wears off, especially once you start eating.  I can see this place being known more for its happy hours than dinners.

The attempt at the cream of brocolli soup was noble, but clearly fell short of anything remarkable or noteworthy.  The pepper crusted petit filet mignon was a bit tough and chewy and cooked rather poorly.  Perhaps the meat was just too old.

What was even more interesting was the mac & cheese croquette.  I had heard the regular mac & cheese was good, so I had higher expectations than to bite into a hardened brick of stale out-of-the-blue-box thing.

As if dessert couldn't come quick enough, the old fashioned chocolate cake was pretty rich and smooth, but so are the ones at Costco.

Besides the food and the mediocre service, I spent more time observing the artwork and decor, especially the grand red chandeliers and the interesting statue of what seem to be figurines dancing in a circle.

If I do come back, it'll probably be to grab a quick drink for happy hour or after getting stamped at Ruby Skye.
author: Tony L.

description: Not bad for a hotel restaurant. We ate here after shopping in Union Square. If you get a table by the window, it's fun to look below upon all the pedestrians. The food was generally good with my watercress soup being one of the best soups I ever had, not too salty as usually soups are from restaurants. The service was polite also, and we got the added treat of voting for the best gingerbread house in the foyer. There were about 5 amazing ones, one of them being the head chef's, the other 4 culinary students.
author: Makelina T.

description:
We stayed for a staycation and decided to bring some alcohol with us to the hotel room. However, the person that did not have to come from work (not me) forgot to pack a knife to cut the limes. Therefore we headed down to the hotel bar to grab a knife and instead ended up hanging out with the bartender and drinking a couple of drinks. 

First we sat at the bar and ordered two drinks off the menu. Definitely delicious. One was like a strawberry mojito, and the other a lemon drop almost. The guy ended up chatting up the bartender and manager at the bar. We tried some interesting drinks - some raspberry liquor that was actually pretty good, some apple whiskey or something that was just way too strong for me, and a root beer type whiskey. I liked the drinks that we bought better, but it was definitely interesting to try something new. 

I had a great time at the bar and would definitely go back and try some of the food there. Great place to drink and hang out.
author: Nina Y.

description: The service was excellent, the drink was yummy (had the "Spring Fling" which was jalapeño infused vodka with elderflower) and the food was tasty - started with the ahi which was ok. A bit unimaginative, just the basic ahi with mango in a sesame soy sauce. The Bison however, was delightful. Cooked perfectly, tender and yummmmmmy.
author: Allie P.

description:
On a rare occasion would you find me hanging out with my girlfriends having Happy Hour bc well with a full work schedule and kids to tend to, it never happens but then again never say never..

I'm a newbie when it comes to happy hour but my my girlfriend works in the neighborhood so she knows the hotspots for HH and so she decided this spot. **Level III is on level 3 on the Marriott Hotel**

When we first stepped out of the elevator and onto the 3rd floor we started searching for the best seats available and so our waiter Jeremy came to our rescue. He escorted us to our seats, handed us our menus and attentively checked in with us. He was great with helping us pick out which items were the tastiest on the menus and which cocktails were the BEST and most importantly he did it all with a GREAT smile! *Like I've mentioned in my reviews countless times, smiles are deal breakers for me and it can turn any grumpy person into a happy one :)

Anywho.. we ended up ordering the sliders *A must have!! Comes with two so it's perfect to share. My thanks to the chef bc these sliders were awesomely tender, juicy patties, warm melted cheese that was foodsgasmic in your mouth after every bite!! Another appetizer we decided on was the chips and salsa. *Hey we were having cocktails and needed something quick to soak up the alcohol before we headed to our next spot. Never before had I seen tortilla chips so perfectly made. The prettiness of these chips matched the hotel itself and I couldn't tell you how much I LOVE their guacamole dip over their salsa dip. I'm usually a salsa person but on this day it was all about their guacamole!! 

Now what kind of cocktails were making us laugh and get all giggly you might ask..  My girlfriend ordered the Pomegranite Martini *I believe she was buzzing after the first couple of sips. LOL. It was an absolute great pick for drinkers like us!* I on the other hand decided to go with the Lemon Drop. *This drink will definitely have you relaxing and dropping in your seat after the second sip. I'm a newbie when it comes to cocktails but I'm a pro when it comes to taking Ms.Henny to the face, funny isn't it?* 

A cozy lounge to kick back and relax. You can have a seat at the bar, dine in at their tables or even hop onto their comfy couches while watching your favorite sport channel. My absolute favorite hot spot for HH :)
author: Anonymous P.

description:
The engineering lead on my team, who had done such a great job, deserved to have a little celebratory lunch to say thank you. I looked around on OpenTable to see what was available. Not much. I called some places. Everything was booked. So I went with the highest rated, nearest place on OpenTable. I went with Level III. What a mistake. We should have ordered a pizza. Let me paint you a picture. This is in real time. I am sitting here with my team. The server is trying his best. He really is. None of this is his fault. He is friendly enough. But he is all by himself. Marooned in the lies of yelp reviews provided by the mechanical turk. My colleague, Ryan, just got his arugula salad. It looks very tired. At least we got our drinks, which were steeped for 15 minutes in benign neglect. My diet coke reminds me of the seldom cleaned soda gun I wielded circa 1989 in a rural Vermont bowling alley.  The ambience is 100% Marriott. That's where Level 3 is located. We are in a hotel. The rug. The tables. The lighting. The music. I am celebrating my team mate's professional achievements in a hotel lobby. Oh. Here is our food! (45 minutes later with an empty restaurant).

My french fries are a little soggy. My burger is "fine" but it costs $16.00.

I am sorry Rob. You deserved so much better.
author: Matthew R.

description: I really enjoyed my sliders and my wine! I don't really think this place deserves more than 3 stars, if we could have got a seat by he fireplace I might give it more stars! Plus your in San Francisco get out of the hotel and explore!
author: Holly G.

description:
Rarely when I am in a city do I eat at a hotel restaurant. After all- there are tons of other places where i can eat. But during my recent trip to the Bay area- Level III was a logical choice for a couple of eating occasions. 

If you go- go for the heirloom tomato salad. Three to four kinds of tomatoes, buffalo mozzarella and garlic toast crumbles all drizzled with balsamic dressing make for a great first start to your meal. This is my favorite of all the items I tried. 

I also had the NY strip (okay but coming from Chicago I guess I expected so much more). It was thin, well prepared but a bit tasteless and I found the mashed potato and pea combination a little odd. 

At another visit I had the tuna poke, that while very artfully arranged, was a bit tasteless. It needed more soy sauce and Wahhabi or anything that would give it some flavor. 

The atmosphere is trendy, the service spot on but know that Level III has fine dining prices. Dinner with drinks ran almost $70 a person which felt steep for a hotel restaurant, although I get they don't want to be considered a "hotel restaurant". They do have a prixe fixe special of a starter, entree and dessert which probably would be the better deal than ordering a la carte. 

Level III has good food, served by friendly people. I guess I'd just prefer if I am paying those kind of prices to be at some trendy place across town!
author: Carol K.

description:
This is a cool spot for an after work meet up. Stop by when they have live music - I caught Sony and Jerry Holland here and heard some excellent tunes.  The Happy Hour menu is hard to beat too. Strong drinks, professional staff, beautiful space and the music swings. 

Also, big plus, the valet parking is free with validated parking stub!
author: Carolyn S.

description:
Jeeeesus Christ, this place is amazing. I would recommend this place to anyone looking for a good place to get together with a couple girlfriends, a couple cocktails and a good time flirting with waiters if that floats your boat. The restaurant is off by the windows and because of the wonderful way it was decorated, you could hardly tell you were in the lobby just inches from the lobby bar. 

I have to say these five stars go to the black truffle mac n cheese. Oh my goodness, the mac and cheese is unlike anything else I've ever had before! There's something special about having black truffles in each and every bite of mac and cheese. The appetizer is served in a cast iron pan thus ensuring each bite is rich and hot 45 minutes into dinner. I have dreams-no nightmares about how good that pasta is. I hate the chef who thought up this dish 'cause he's ruined me for Southern Comfort food now. 

Okay, so besides that, we also had:

Chicken sticks: This is basically Thai satay chicken right down to the skewers and peanut sauce.

Flight of Kobe Beef, Crabcake Sandwich, and Pulled Pork Sandwich: Honestly, I was too stuffed from the appetizer to really dig into it too much but the presentation was beautiful and the gherkin pickles they found to adorn the tops of each burger made it that much more delightful.

Flatbread Pizza: This is a classic Italian style pizza with just the right balance with fresh arugula and tomatoes. I love how the arugula gives the pizza a kick that put it over the top. 

So I'll come back to this place one day when I lose the 10 lbs. I gained from inhaling all that mac and cheese. I'll see it in my dreams tonight probably...damn it.
author: Jessica K.

description:
The Good: The food was amazing, the desserts are to die for.

The Bad: The food took a long time to arrive.

The Review: Let me first say that I do not usually eat at fine dining restaurants so I was a little out of my element here.  Level III has a great deal called the Prixe Fix Menu.  It is $39 and includes your choice of one appetizer, one entree, and a dessert.  Considering the prices of the entrees this is a really good deal.  I had the scallops, the portobello ravioli, and the Apple Grunt.  The scallop starter was exquisite.  I don't know what was in it but trust me when I saw it was delicious.  The ravioli was good, but I felt it was too much...as in the sauce was a little overpowering, the portobello raviolis were delish though.  If a delicious cheesecake and a scrumptious apple pie made sweet love their baby would be the Apple Grunt dessert.  It was decadent.  I also had a few bites of the filet mignon, man it was so good.

The ambiance was really nice, as the restaurant just flows from the lobby area.  Our table remarked that it could have been a little more dim to set a better mood.  The service was great, they came by often to refill our drinks and check on us.  Unfortunately the kitchen didn't follow suit.  The food took a really long time to get out there.  It took a good while before we got our first appetizer, and then it seemed like we were waiting awhile for our entrees.  That aside the food really made up for this.
author: Joel S.

description:
Decent food. Attractive surroundings.  Great service. 

There are zillions of restaurant choices in San Fran. This one wouldn't be a recommendation.  Not bad, just not wow.
author: Kimberly S.

description: Rubbish. Hideously overpriced, with an indifferent staff and food pooped out of a Popeil's Cuisine Californicator, this place is just sad debris left in the wake of the pressure wave of yuppy bullshit that threatens to destroy the restaurant scene in the city. Leave it to the unfortunate hotel guests.
author: John H.

description:
We stopped in for drinks after having dinner in Union Square.  The bar and restaurant are quite trendy looking and reside in a large open space.  I enjoyed the look and took the time to appreciate the design that someone created. ( an idea suggested in the book A Whole New Mind).
Drinks were well mixed by a personable local mixologist.  Conversation flowed easily.  It was nice to get out of the comfort zone of one's regular haunts.
author: Thomas D.

description:
3.5 stars rounded up because of the nice service!

My bf was definitely not in a good mood tonight as he's doing his taxes at the last minute (I'm the opposite, did mine in February).  Ugh, so I left the house to get some air and a quick dinner.  An acquaintance once told me that the Happy Hour at Level III at the Marriott was worth checking out.

It's not far from my place - somehow I found myself there tonight.  Nice ambiance and friendly service.  I just made it in time for the tail end of the Happy Hour (M-F 4-7PM).  I ordered the Mac and Cheese (with gruyere, mascarpone, and parmigiano reggiano topped with toasted breadcrumbs) - pretty darn decent and it filled me up quick!  I also ordered artichoke dip (a-ok) with house tortilla chips and the house pinot noir (smooth, just what I needed).  Ahhh, I was hungry and that all hit the spot, especially the pinot.    

Thank you, Level III for saving my evening and giving me a good break from my grumpy, tax-stressed bf - ugh!  ;)  

P.S.  He's in a slightly better mood now - thank goodness!

2 Happy Hour dishes+1 glass of house pinot noir+tip+tax = $28
author: Maile N.

description:
This place has an awesome atmosphere.
The dining options were very American, but with a more high class take on it.
Their Macaroni and Cheese was the best I've ever had, large portion with a crispy top and hot, creamy insides.
When I got to desserts, I was in heaven. Their creme brulee, apple pie, and chocolate cake are to die for.
LOVE IT! Will be coming back!
author: Christopher S.

description: Watched one of the Giants playoff baseball games here. It was fun and a nice place to chill out. Everything here is expensive. Clam chowder was my favorite. Everything was to chic and trendy for me. I'm more of a meat and potatoes guy. If your into fancy food you will probably like it better than me. Did I mention that it was pretty expensive especially for the portion size! The Giants won so that made it a great experience.
author: Jeff C.

description:
Need a place for a business diner or visiting parents or just have a group with a range of diets? Level III is a good option for you. While the food isn't the most creative every dish we had was cooked perfectly. We were a group of six and ended up being there for Dine about Town which can be a hit or miss.

They had two options for first and third course and we tried everything. 

The first course was either a greens salad of a cauliflower soup. The soup was the most creative dish of the night and had a complex flavour and wasn't too creamy or heavy.

The green salad was ok but forgettable.

The entrees were all excellent. Two of us got the filet mignon which is one of my favorite cuts. I had mine medium rare and the other person had their medium well and both of our meat was cooked to order and tasted great.

The fish dish was an arctic char that was prepared well and had nice accompaniments.

The vegetarian entree was a butternut squash tortellini which probably was the most complex and interesting entree and was a dish we all agreed we would have again. It had a nice spiced almost floral sauce.

We ended with the dessert which was old fashioned chocolate cake and cheese course. The cake was super moist and creamy. The cheese was decent but the dried fruit served with it was rather anemic and should have just be left off.

Those of us that drink were unimpressed with the wine list. They did have fake cocktails which were tasty.

The service was absent. They forgot to give us a wine list  when we sat down and then came back and asked if we wanted to order wine. The food came out at a good pace but the server seemed missing in action for most of the night.
author: DeathandFood H.

description:
3 is a great number for this place - it's on the third level of the JW Marriott, it's about 3 $$$, and it's getting 3 stars. 

As one reviewer pointed out, the purpose of Dine About Town is to try dishes at restaurants you'd otherwise not visit. DAT is to showcase what a restaurant does creatively and get you to come back. While there was nothing technically wrong with the dishes' execution - NY Strip came out medium-rare, as requested, veggies were flavorful, etc. - there wasn't anything outstanding. You put mac and cheese with steak on a DAT menu? Salmon on a bed of spinach? Solid, but really lacking in the creativity department here.

The one outstanding thing was the service, but not in a good way. Level III was dead empty on a Saturday night, with one server running the show for the entire place. Spoons for soup were forgotten, and the server seemed to disappear completely between courses. We actually had to get up and search for her when it came time to settle the check, since we were left twiddling our thumbs in front of empty dessert plates for about 15 minutes and the time window for our valet parking (Level III validates 2 hours for free) was running out.

Pity the poor souls who pay full price for this. I guess it's a good option if you're staying at the JW and don't have 2 minutes to walk a block to a better restaurant.
author: Sherry W.

description:
The food melted in my mouth! Tasty sliders, macaroni and cheese (needed more mushrooms), and desserts disappeared as soon as they were put out at the Yelp event I attended. When I tasted these treats, I could understand why. 

Level III serves unique and adequately stiff cocktails in a pretty setting. I love the red decor and the stunning view the hollow center provides - an open view of the many floors between you and the rooftop.
author: Jaime L.

description: My partner and I had a nice meal here once, for their prix fix. It was great. I went back recently for their "happy hour." I use quotes because there was nothing happy about paying $8 for a glass of okay wine during happy hour. That's their version of happy hour!? Down the street at Jones you can get seriously half off food and drinks for way better. Rip off of a happy hour if I ever saw one. It's a joke.
author: Mark S.

description:
A generous three stars.

-The decor was pleasant but we were seated at a table where the light fixture, hanging from the ceiling, was so low and off center of the table that it was actually a distraction.

-The service was iffy. The server took our order, sans smile, and said bread would be right out.  It took about 15 minutes,  just prior to our soup and salad.

I had filet mignon with macaroni and cheese which was good and my wife had salmon which was OK.  At no time did the waiter come back and check on us which was amazing considering there was only one other table with guests at the time.

Not a restaurant I will revisit.
author: Jeff H.

description:
Food = mediocre.  A bit overpriced if you ask me.  *shrugs* But I guess it doesn't matter.  They do have a happy hour...which may entice you.  

Drinks = decent list.  

Decor = Simple, warm hues, modern but cozy feel.  I'd ask for more tables though in the 'lounge-y" area, since they serve food there, but there is no way that you can eat everything on regular plates on your lap.

Service = friendly enough.
author: Fannie S.

description:
I went to Level 3 to meet up with friends who were in town and staying at the hotel. If they wouldn't have told me about it, I never would have found it and that would have been a shame! 
 I ordered from the happy hour menu, so I am not sure what the regular menu looks likeI started with the house pinot noir and I really liked it. I should have asked what brand it was because I really really liked it. I split the mac and cheese and sliders with my friend, it was the perfect amount of food. The mac and cheese had Gruyere, Mascarpone, and Parmigiano Reggiano Topped with Toasted Breadcrumbs - it was delicious and just what I needed after a few drinks. The American Kobe Sliders had Crispy Cipollini Onion Rings, Sonoma Pepperjack, Tomato and Cornichon. They were some of the best Kobe sliders I have ever had. 
The service was good, even though it was off hours our server was very attentive and handling all the tables. If I am in the area again, I will definitely stop by and check out their regular menu.
author: Alycia N.

description:
Strictly for their Happy Hour:  M-F 4-7pm

We were going to shop in Union Square and I yelped ahead of time for some Happy Hours to hit while we are in SF to take advantage of them.  Level III was the first of three that day.

It's a cool lounge.  Plenty seating throughout.  Very open.  Nice bar.  Bartender was a bit aloof.  Great Happy Hour menu.  We had:

American Kobe Sliders - three mini delights served with crispy cipollini
onion rings, sonoma pepperjack, tomato and fresh brioche buns - $6 - nice presentation and tasty mini burgers.  We had it medium rare and that was exactly how it was served.  A slider never tasted better.

Bistro fries - house seasoned fries served with parmesan and parsley - $3.50 - very crispy but was salty.  Addicting but got too salty after a while.  As hubby said - it's a bar, that's how they sell more drinks!

I had the shanghaied - square one cucumber, canton ginger liqueur, and organic lemongrass syrup, shaken and served up with an english cucumber slice on the rim - $6.  A bit too sweet for my liking but interesting.  Hubby had the Anchor Steam draft for $4.  

For a Friday, it was a bit slow.  After an hour, there were only a few patrons but it was time to head out to other Happy Hours.  If we are ever in the neighborhood, we will definitely return.
author: Gloria H.

description:
At first, I was a little disappointed that this place was physically on level 3 at the Marriott.  But then, the fun/ slightly swanky yet trendy and vibrant decor turned me back on. They have decent house music which was a plus. 
The food was good. Sliders were excellent. 
Not sure if I would come back though...
author: Rada I.

description: I met a friend who was in town for a conference here for dinner. As a person who often wanders around larger hotels aimlessly until I get oriented, this place is ridiculously easy to find. It on the third floor, or more precisesly, on level 3 just as its name implies.  I especially love the dramatic decor, that includes vibrant splashes of color and a large scale fountain with a ring of dancers frolicking around it. Service is friendly, and the food is good. I particularly like the mac and cheese. With the addition of some lobster, the small portion was a decadent morsel. It was so rich, I'm not sure I would have been able to eat the large.The fish tacos are also excellent. It seems like a quite spot in general, and it was great for conversation.Some of the menu options seemed intriguing.  If I was going to ACT or something else around Union Square, I might give it another go.
author: Nicole M.

description: This was a great place to stop after a long day of walking and sight seeing. My mom is in town visiting me in the city, and we wanted to try something new and fun. We were skeptical of going to a bar in a hotel, but were extremely surprised. The service was out of this world. Dan- the bartender- was extremely personable and made us feel at home. Another waiter went out of his way to take my phone and charge it for me when he heard me wondering if there was an outlet anywhere. Needless to say, it was a great experience and I'll definitely be visiting again.
author: Rachel E.

description:
Came here a couple of times...the first time was for an event..the second time with several girlfriends. 

The service was extrememly slow..I waited 10 minutes before the cocktail waitress came by to take my order. To add insult to injury, she charged some of us the full amount for the wines we order because apparently she placed the order right after the happy hour cut-off. ..WTH? 

The food is uninteresting...doubt I'd go back again to endure the crappy service.
author: Mimi T.

description:
How many different ways are there to say the word "awesome"? If it wouldn't annoy people, I'd list them all for this restaurant. 

They are never crowded, it seems, which makes you worry they must not be good, but don't let that scare you off. 

The restaurant is on the third floor (naturally) of a hotel. 

The food is FANTASTIC. I got these scallops as an appetizer and they were so good I asked the waiter if they'd consider making them into a main course. He told me many other patrons have asked the same question. The service is stellar. A manager always comes by to make sure you're enjoying your meal. 

This is a place that truly wants you to enjoy your experience there. They will allow almost any substitutions you request. Love it. Oh, and the bathrooms are across the lobby, and very clean.
author: Green Y.

description: My husband and I stay at this JW Marriott in Union Square whenever we visit San Francisco, usually once a year or more. We have always LOVED the Onion Soup and Mac&Cheese which are both incredible. On this last visit we ate twice in this restaurant, and got food to go once. I must say the food is good, but EXTREMELY overpriced with EXTREMELY limited choices. In fact, they no longer serve the mainstays at all despite being told that we could "find the FULL menu online at 'levelIIIsf.com'". We did this, saw some fairly great choices, cancelled our high priced, fantastic steakhouse reservations outside the hotel only to find upon arriving in Level III that the online menu had been completely changed 5 days before, and the hotel is slow in getting the website changed!!!!!  Needless to say we were beyond disappointed to have to pay $106 for two 6oz Fillet Mignons with ONLY one side each!!!!  No special sauce or anything, just the steak and a side of potatoes for me, and spinach for husband. Way, way, way overpriced.  Disappointed at how the JW Marriott could have this sort of miscommunication when completely revamping the menu to the ONLY restaurant in the hotel. Unacceptable and unprofessional. At least they still have the fabulous Mac&Cheese with truffle oil!!!!!
author: Vicki M.

description: I am writing as a local, as a person who doesn't normally do happy hour, but I gotta say, after stopping by on a whim to check out the music there (as a former NYer its hard to find live music anywhere in SF that isn't noise) I was very pleasantly surprised -- the place is a little gem tucked away in the somewhat merciless Union Square area. Nice service -- okay the martini I ordered had ice chips in it, kinda a pet peeve of mine -- but the ambiance (I know! we're talking about a hotel here!) -- was very soothing, a big fireplace always helps.  The music -- a pretty blonde crooner and chill guitar accompaniment, just made it all perfect.  Will definitely be going back, hope the music is still there.
author: Mark P.

description:
************* REVIEW 258 ****************

Located inside the Marriott Hotel. I haven't been here for awhile so when my relative in town & stayed here, I figure might as well. The place  is still nice & the bar was busy with loud sport watchers as usual.

What we ordered:

- Kobe Sliders - & I asked for extra pickled,  so yummy!
- French Onion Soup - a bit salty.
- Mixed Green Salads - nice & fresh dressing.
- Mussel - was nice side, but the broth was good for dipping.
- Stripe Bass with risotto & veggies - the cream sauce was a bit much over the rice. It was almost like a risotto, except the
- NY Steak - was also over cooked for my cousin.
- Scallop & cheese ball over a a bed of zuccini salad - nice.
- Duo shortrib & Filet - The shortrib was nice, but the filet was medium!

Service was just OK this time. Our server tried, but he didn't bring out the dishes at the same time. He didn't really know where the ingredients come from when we asked for it. He had to get back to us. That just fail me right there. The service seemed lacking the smoothness, compared the last few times I was here which was a year ago!

Overall: 3.5 stars
For value: 4 stars
For Food: 3 stars
For Service: 3.5 stars 
For ambiance: 3 stars
For Crowd: Too crowded, we were near the bar!
For location: Valet is only!
author: Manda Bear B.

description: Yes this is a hotel restaurant but the fact that nobody knows about it is a great plus. I came for dine about town and was pretty impressed with the service and food. You get top-notch hotel service and high-end furniture which already makes the experience very positive. Throw on a great seafood chowder with chunks of crab meat and a nicely portioned steak frites and it becomes a surprisingly well-rounded meal.
author: Ed L.

description:
This is like a gem hidden deep in the earth's crust. Bumping into this place also feels like that. Its hard to notice the restaurant from the exterior since there is only one sign. Sure its large and impressive but thats what this place needs, more signage. But lets get to the food and service.

  When you enter the MARRIOTT HOTEL, one can start to smell the intellectual gastronomy in the air. My wife and I had to take a very modern elevator to, yes you guessed it, LEVEL III. The place was not too busy. Vibes of working people getting off work for a late afternoon drink. Nice. Plenty of people with suits and business attire. My wife and I were seated right away and our server (Mike or Michael) recommended the famous HAPPY HOUR drinks and small plates. It was a great afternoon chatting and trying to pick out the tourist from the locals. After drinks and appetizers, our server spoke about the changes made to LEVEL III and how the menu rotates from week to week. If you never been there, check it out. I think you would be pleasantly surprised.
author: Edson C.

description:
I've never been in the JW Marriott and I was pleasantly surprised.  It's a really nice space.  It's a bit confusing when you walk in on level 3 because you're at Reception for checking into the hotel when you get off of the elevator.  It's not totally obvious that the restaurant is just past it.  

We wee there for lunch and our group ordered the mac and cheese, the seafood chowder, and the sample plate of three desserts for ten bucks.  The mac and cheese and chowder received rave reviews.  I was the one who ordered the dessert and I picked the butterscotch pudding, peanut butter chocolate crunch bar, and creme brulee.  The pudding and brulee were tasty, though not the best I've had.  The bar was so rich that after one bite I was done.  I didn't like it at all so then I asked if I could have the chocolate cookies instead.  Those weren't all that special either.

For ten bucks total, overall, I got a good value.  The booths were super comfy, and you could certainly hang out for hours chatting with your pals.  The server, I believe his name was Drew, was exceptionally nice and took great care in making sure we were served well.  We were 1 of only 2 tables taken in the place, so I'm sure that helped :-P
author: Tamar D.

description: I was really disappointed with this place. While the food was decent, that is about the only thing to say. For as high as everything was priced, I had expected a much better experience.
author: Ashley J.

description:
Visited Level III on Friday night, where it was an unseasonably warm 90+ degrees in S.F.; it's important to know that in reading this review. Can't blame the restaurant for the weather, but it did make me notice that my seat was parked right under a very low, very hot chandelier. Pretty, but very hot. The service and food were very good, but the lighting should be reconsidered. 

Our waiter was very attentive and did an excellent job, despite working in the heat. The food? Yum. We had salads for starters, which were nice but the entrees were breathtaking. My mac and cheese featured a crumbly crunchy top and the shaved black truffle was the ultimate in upscale comfort food. I was panting halfway through, though- it's a huge serving (photo above). The tuna tartare was the wiser choice for a warm night and was accompanied by an avocado cream that was smooth and refreshing. Both dishes were excellent. The "amuse bouche" with crab was out of this world- the chef scored big points with us there! It was citrus-y and slightly sweet (from the crab) and salty, and all that flavor packed into a tiny glass. Sadly, we were too full for dessert but we'll be back- hopefully before this place gets crowded.
author: Joi W.

description:
It really is on the III level of the Marriott, so I was thrown off just a bit when we first arrived. I did set reservations but really didn't need to because we walked in to a ghost town.

The experience once we on to the III floor was great , the location looked very modern which set the mood. The custom service was excellent, our waitress was extremely attentive. The food ( Fix Menu)  was extremely well done!

over all we left satisfied and extremely confident that this was a good choice our a special dinner !
author: Steve S.

description: I wish I could come here everyday! Food is awesome and so is Joseph! We came 2 days in a row and we got lucky to have Joseph take care of us. He really made our visit more memorable. Always having a smile on his face and he works very hard.  My son loves the mac and cheese and for me, filet mignon. Thank you so much for being so awesome and making our visit so wonderful!
author: Linda M.

description: We enjoyed our stay @ JW - Marriot & decided to try their in-house restaurant/ bar (Level III)... A little pricey but Food was great... :-)
author: Yurey P.

description: First and last time I will eat here.  Food was decent but uninspired and incredibly over priced.  Some of the wait staff were difficult to understand. The manager should recognize that a close to empty restaurant on a Saturday night in San Francisco is a warning he/she should be noting.
author: Ginger L.

description:
A shockingly mediocre experience.  Every few years, I have a definingly mediocre dining experience that then becomes a reference point for all others, until it is superceded or has finally worked it's way through my system.  Level III is my new level 4 bad dining experience and the one that inspired me to finally sign up for Yelp just in order to lay down some feedback. 

I don't know how any restaurant with this remarkably low standard of service and quality, can survive in a competitive San Francisco market.  I think it must solely survive on the captured hotel guest clientele that are too lazy to venture down the street, though I see other reviews here that suggest people intentionally come here.   My mistake, as last minute Thanksgiving travel plans imploded and we found ourselves instead at a Union Sq hotel restaurant and at the mercy.  

So, our expectations were low to begin with but we were in an appropriately celebratory mood going in.  Level III took care of that in a hurry.  Stiff, unfriendly, unprofessional, lacking in basic social and service skills, from host, to waitress, bus boy.   I'm pretty sure our waitress had not worked in that capacity more than 2 days before bumbling through our evening.  We had to flag her down almost a dozen times just to keep water in our glass, a fork on the table, "we still have entrees coming right?".  Even our visa card at the end of the night went missing for a time.   The staff couldn't get out of their own way, let alone ours.    

The food?  I would coin it cafeteria-lousy.  It was so poorly executed (and I'm not a food snob, really)  that we sat across from each other, politely picking through our dry, tendon-laden Thanksgiving meal, before finally requesting an extra ladle of gravy just to be able to grease it down our throats.  Seriously, I've had better dinners at Pinewood Derby award dinners. 

We walked out of there not only embarrassed to have overspent for a thoroughly mediocre experience, but also challenged by a 2 hour struggle that threatened to suck the life out of the rest of the evening.   The final kick in the head came with the bill to learn that our small, weak cocktails (Saphirre & tonic) were $12 each!   Level III = Lousy Lesson Learned.
author: Span D.

description:
Ok, I had to sign up for yelp just to give a review on this place! 

Service: AWESOME! I had Zack at the bar help my friends and I out, we got the jalapeno lemondrop's and some grey goose martini's, he is great! made some bomb drinks. And Zack the turned us over to our waitress Layla, she was fantastic as well. She was cute & funny and gave us great suggestions on food! We had the Mac & Cheeses, which was soooo creamy and good. And we ordered the sweet potato fries, the apple grunt, the Sliders, and the Ahi Tuna! ALL of it was truly AMAZING! Good job for a Marriott, I was impressed! I will def come back for more!
author: Larry C.

description:
Was happy when I first found this place and used to come fairly often but now I'm rethinking it:

Pluses: Wednesday through Friday Jazz (more lounge music) - Sony Holland is great and hits the spot in winding down after work. The place, while 80-ish, is very spacious and seating has never been a problem. I also like the fact that they have a work bench with plugs so I can even finish up some work without feeling like a buzz kill in the lobby/ bar. 

Minuses: Pretty much everything else - the Happy Hour is not really a Happy Hour as wines on and off the Happy Hour list are around the same price. Apps and food are overpriced and nothing special. 

Wait staff is hit or miss. The young-ish waiters and waitresses are on point and friendly. The older waitresses aren't very friendly and don't seem to know the drink menus that well. One time I asked for an Old Fashioned and the older waitress said she'll check if they had that 'brand' Another time I asked the waitress if she had a sweet white wine by the glass for my wife. She said, "No" so I took a look at the menu and found a glass of riesling was in fact available. What ticked me off though was I ordered a 'SideCar'. Well mixed drinks are listed as $6 during happy hour. When I got the bill, she charged me $10 and it said 'well-whiskey' on the receipt. I asked her about it and she said she used extra alcohol. I told her a sidecar is not made with whiskey. She said she 'knew' but had to charge it that way??? It would have at least been nice if she let me know she would have to charge it as extra before giving me a bill with a bogus whiskey charge.

New plan; Farallon down the street has an AMAZING happy hour and impeccable service. Head there first - fill up. Head to Level III, order a beer (hard to get that wrong) to listen to Sony and just tip her directly!
author: Parag G.

description:
Came here with friends during the Dine About Town Special. 

Very average. Food was OK. If we didn't go during the Dine About Town, I would have felt ripped off for the price they charge. 

Nothing special or memorable.

The Eggs says: Average, just average.
author: Cindy W.

description:
Like many others, I found our service was awful. Never checked on us. The bus boys pretty much took care of us throughout the evening. Took 25 minutes to get our check - which we had to get up and ask for. No one to be found, so we wandered to the kitchen to get assistance. The table near us had a similar experience. The lady at that table decided to yell for help though.....
Avoid "Andrew" as a server & you might be ok.
author: Miss G.

description:
Good place, not excellent. The mac & cheese is the best thing on the menu. Flat bread pizzas are really good too. The Kobe beef sliders are amazing. Go at least for the drinks. Specialty drinks created by a local mix-ologist are excellent. 

Oh and get the french onion soup. One of the best I've EVER had.
author: Colleen M.

description: Happy Hour in the hotel lobby is good. Decent food and price but nothing I'd rave over. Service can be slow at times but otherwise is good.
author: Anna S.

description:
Our family of 5 went for the prix fixe.  The first course was excellent (seafood sampler and day boat scallops).  Most of our group ordered the filet mignon and nobody was happy with that.  It was advertised as peppercorn encrusted but what came on the plate was a gray, plain piece of steak.  Very disappointing.  I had the gnocchi with steak and lobster, it was good but not worth the $39 prix fixe price.  (I think I was the only one who was happy with their meal!)  
My advice is to skip the prix fixe and stick with appetizers.
author: Nancy S.

description:
Did you know this place existed? Neither did I. Neither does the entire population of San Francisco, apparently. 

My friend made a reservation here for his birthday for a party of 6. We were running late and I immediately went into typical "being late for a restaurant in SF" mode of "OMG, they're gonna pass up our table, we'll have to wait another hour, we're missing 1 person so they won't sit us until we get there" and so on. 

The joke was on me. 

We got there, rushing to the restaurant and barely appreciating the gorgeous open atrium of the hotel, when we found the check in table and started looking around. 

"Huh. The restaurant must be somewhere behind all these empty tables and chairs. I wonder why they're walking us through them. Oh. They're seating us here? At this table. All alone in the entire place. Maybe it's just a waiting area. Yeah, maybe the real dining area is hidden in a secret place. Oh, no. They just brought us menus. This really is Level III. Well, let's hope we make it out alive."

In all honesty, the place is pretty cute but the food was average. I've never used the word "meh" to describe something, but this place feels like it deserves a "meh." 

MEH. Meh. meh. meeeeeehhhh.

They have a prix fixe menu for $39/person including an appetizer, dinner and desert. From what I tasted of others' meals, I'm not sure it was entirely worth the price. I ended up choosing the halibut tacos and Caesar salad. Neither were memorable. AND the fish was fried. So weird! Who puts fried fish in fish tacos. What a let down!

But kudos to our waiter. He was pretty awesome, patient yet attentive, and even brought the birthday boy a glass of champagne.
author: Jared S.

description:
WHERE: third floor of the marriott hotel. POST st.
interior decor was on point. christmas tree/ornaments/lights, fireplace, had the game on, full bar nearby... scrumptious.

$$: prix fixe menu was $40.

FOOD: two orders of fries, not on the prix fixe, not too soggy, a tad salty, but good garlic:fry ratio.

pan boat scallops were a bit under cooked, tasty though. ahi tuna tataki had avocado slices and the sauce? ..CRACKEN!

seared salmon was ehh.. kind of bland? came with garlic sauteed spinach and bits of crab. and the butter based organic chicken breast was a little dry. was on a bed of cheese risotto which was delicious, and a mushroom gravy sauce?

too full so i didn't even try the dessert. we left and it wasn't finished, i assume it was 3/5 stars. our waitress michelle was very friendly and redid a gin martini that was a little watery. restaurant was empty and our water glasses stayed empty also.. for too long

OVERALL: for the price, i'd try somewhere else next time. the company was spectacular and its in a great location so still had a great time!
author: Braden K.

description: Great hang out place for some appetizers and drinks.  I thought the mini burgers were good and the mac and cheese was too.  The chocolate chip ice cream sandwich was really good!  I'm more of a savory person, but I have to say those sandwiches were good.  I also thought the cocktails they were serving were very unique and sounded scary, but they were actually very tasty and refreshing.  Never would have think Jim Beam with homemade apple cider would taste good together. But yes it did!  I wasn't liking how the area was so spread out, but I guess its good for those hotel lounge/bar areas.  It's a big space and there's tables that are far from the bar, so the waitress (if there is one) will have a hard time seeing you if you needed something.
author: Gina S.

description:
My old good friend took me out to this place on a Sunday night  and I really enjoyed this restaurant. Food was delicious and the environment was elegant and quiet. We could catch up many things without any interference. We stayed for almost 2 hours but servers were very nice and didn't seem to care so much~ 

I returned to this restaurant with other good friend when I had to tell her about my recent problems with love life. I think this restaurant is a certainly good place if you want a quiet environment with nice trendy decoration. Place doesn't seem to get crowded and the food was served pretty quickly. I hope there are more dishes on the menu to choose from, but I enjoyed squash pasta, oyster, taco, and chicken salad I had here.
author: Sunny K.

description: Nice place, great hh food, insane hoops to jump thru to get wifi!  Would come again if I don't need wifi
author: Jon B.

description:
You know when you're speaking with someone for the first time and they're trying to make an effort to be really warm and engaging but they come off as slightly chilly in disposition?

Level III is a gorgeous place, and the bar staff is extremely efficient. However, when such an expansive (as in large) place is practically empty, I involuntarily shiver.

DRINKS: A great Happy Hour menu; better than most upscale places in Union Square. A friend/colleague went with me, and since we're both industry people, the bartender made us off-menu cocktails for a couple hours. Great prices. 

EATS: One should never order food when already drunk. But in the case you're rewarding yourself for a hard week's work, please do! The chicken wings are amazing, as are the parm fries. There are all on the Happy Hour menu, and come in rather well-suited portions; enough for two alcoholics, or for four rather sober people wanting snackies.

ATMOSPHERE: The splashes of red in an otherwise austere layout remind me of religious goings-on. The glass elevators are gorgeous, but the seating for Level III is somewhat off to the side of the lounge bar. It's almost like the tables were an afterthough. Granted, the bar was converted after the hotel was taken over, so the designers didn't have the choice of complete remodeling.

Also, the open ceiling into a 20+ floor building? You really feel tiny. Also, it's never wise to crain one's neck upwards after they've been drinking!
author: C. P.

description: Hotel food is always the way to go. This was a last minute decision, but so worth it. Really, really good prices for what they had. The crab cake sliders are TO DIE FOR. And the nut assortment was a very generous serving for the cost. Good, speedy service, too. An odd bar, but delicious. I'd go again!
author: Elisë K.

description:
The food was great. We had the fries (which were supposed to be sweet potato but she brought us garlic instead), kobe sliders, prix fixe menu of corn bisque, ravioli and artisan cheeses with the wine pairing. And for dessert the apple grunt, mini ice cream sandwiches and vanilla creme brulee (best dessert I have ever had). 
The fries were great. The kobe burgers were amazing. Super tasty bun, and the meat juicy and flavorful. The bisque was sweet and delicious. Ravioli had a great sauce. Cheeses were just ok. 
Wait staff was slow...lots of time between courses. Nice layout to the eating area. Felt very spacious. GREAT decor. AWESOME location
author: Katie C.

description:
Swanky.

They have a really nice lounge, including some booths by the windows with your own personal televisions. My friend and I sat in some large chairs by the fireplace and enjoyed cocktails and Parmesan fries. I was really impressed with the cocktail menu- they came up with some unique drinks and many were San Francisco themed. I tried Emperor Norton's Mistress, which was Makers Mark with muddled strawberries, Cointreau and Navan. Our waiter was really nice and we enjoyed chatting with him.  

 Seems like a good place to end the evening on a really good date, or a quiet location to rendezvous for an affair.  I mean that in a good way!
author: Lisa R.

description:
Ok, so what if it's in the Marriott? Level III has helped redefine the new hotel lobby. It's a lounge, a restaurant, a meeting area and workspace all in one. It's wide open, yet intimate when the occasion calls for it. 

Drinks are not inexpensive, but with a menu from H. Joseph Ehrmann (of Elixir fame http://www.yelp.com/biz/elixir-san-francisco), they do deliver on quality and originality. The Harvey Milk Punch comes in 3 levels of the Big Easy classic; I'm not sure who's ordering the level 3 cuvee du cent-cinquantenaire at $90 a glass but let me know if you do, but the level 1 at $15 is a relative deal. The Shaghaied at $15 is also tasty, and the description of the cocktail lets you know that "you'll go willingly on this Chinese journey," and I want to believe them.

But I'd say the real pleasant surprise for me was the food, namely the bar snacks. Items like: bistro fries seasoned with salt and pepper; a mac and cheese made up of gruyere, mascarpone, and parmeggiano reggiano; and kobe beef sliders on mini brioche buns. Mmm!

Whether it's after a hard day of work or shopping, definitely keep Level III in mind. It's a place that deserves to be more of a destination. I'm also intrigued by their Take 3 Happy Hour: 3 reds, 3 whites, 3 beers, 3 cocktails, 3 plates, 3 hours,  1/2 price, 4-7 Monday-Friday. Three is indeed the magic number.
author: Nish N.

description:
Had I read my fellow yelpers' reviews before dining here, I might have expected the restaurant to be completely empty, like it was. I met my dining companion about 30 minutes before our reservation (They apparently wouldn't let us have an earlier one.) with the intention of grabbing a drink at the bar.  No need to worry, though since NO ONE was at the restaurant.

Service was very attentive, but the food seemed sub-par.  I had a half-order of mac & cheese, which was good, and my steak sandwich was fine, but the fries were way too salty!

And I ordered a caramel ice cream sundae, which took me approximately 1.5 bites to eat! And the ice cream wasn't even very good!

The highlight of the night was seeing this guy passed out by the bar and the hotel manager had to shake to wake him up.  I couldn't hear their discussion, but the sleepy patron seemed upset that he'd been roused from his sleep, then promptly tilted his head back and closed his eyes again once the manager walked away.
author: Marcus C.

description:
Level three has so many things going against it, and they haven't overcome that.

Let's start with the building.  It is a ridiculous building, a hideous mid budget glass elevator monstrosity with exposed duct work that has always reminded me above all else of the atrium from the death star.

And then the setting, it is a Mariott.  Mariott has never stood for hip or cool, I'm not sure what it stands for but clueful is not it.  Mariott doing ultra lounge is like tuedo on a monkey.  Maybe I would rather see the monkey.

And Union Square, that's tough competition.  Within a few blocks are the Saint Francis, Campton Place, Fairmont, Sir Francis Drake, Mark Hopkins, Ritz, Omni, plus any number of boutique hoels.  If you come to San Francisco and your boss puts you up in the Mariott you've got rocky times ahead my friend.

Amidst all this, somebody studied the success of the W and all the boutique hotels and said, lets do this!   In fact, let's take it up a notch!

So now there's an utterly sprawling, vast restaurant lounge lobby that takes up the entire surface (other than the news stand and the elevators) of the main floor of the hotel, floor 3.  They have every conceivable amenity and seating arrangements - formal tables, couches, bar seating, bar tables, banquettes, long Cat 5 enabled computer hookup tables, Internet pay stations, semi-private flat screen roomlets (at least a dozen of those), fireplace seating, and beds.  Yes, you can even plop yourself down in one of their lobby beds and order from there.  It's nuts I tell you.

For all this, service is slow and haphazard.  Food is middling to terrible, menu is not thought out well.  Drinks are well designed but not well executed (names like Harvey Milk Punch, Marina Margarita, Emperor Norton's Mistress, Dirty Harry).  The prices are unconscionable - $8 for a draft beer????   Hello, this is not the Saint Regis.  At happy hour they have a small number of half price options which just makes it a normally priced bad meal instead of something you kick yourself in the head wishing you didn't.

The best part of the place is the design and layout.  It is pretty cool to lookout, and not bad to hang out.  If only the food, service, vibe, and prices were at that level.  But even the design, it's still in the lobby of the death star, it looks as if somebody put an ultralounge in Darth Vader's palace.
author: Gil S.

description:
I would have probably never known of this place if I hadn't sampled some of their food at an event in San Francisco, but they know what they are doing. It is strange that it is in an open hotel lobby with just some curtains separating diners from hotel patrons checking in, but that makes this restaurant a little different, which I kind of like. If you are looking for a private dining experience then this is probably not your place. However, the food was very good.

I took advantage of the Price Fix menu paired with wine. I have been on a soup binge lately and started with a carrot puree, which was not the best ever, but was a good way to start the meal. For my main course I had the Filet Minon. It was lightly seasoned and cooked to perfection! The way a piece of meat is cooked means everything to me and they nailed it. I actually went to a place "famous for steaks" a week later and was longing for the cut I had at Level III. That is pretty impressive when you can outshine a famous steakhouse. The dessert I chose was the cheese platter because I don't like sweet at the end of a meal. They missed a bit on this. They weren't the best cheeses and the accompanying items on the plate just didn't work.

I would try this place again and recommend it to others if they are not sure where they feel like eating. The Scallops looked delicious and I would try them next time. The price is about what you would expect from similar restaurants in SF, so you won't feel ripped off. The one thing to keep in mind is that there is little to no privacy, so if you are looking to be secluded while you eat this is not your place.
author: Frank J.

description:
I just found my dinner receipt in my pocket* and realized that beers at Level III were $8 a piece. $8! I don't have a problem paying $8 for a beer at a concert or at a cool Belgian bar but in a glorified hotel restaurant? No thanks! 

No wonder the place was almost empty on a Saturday night. I will definitely not be returning unless it's during happy hour when everything's half price.

*great filing system, eh?
author: phil h.

description:
Although it sits in the tourist-heavy Marriott hotel in Union Square, locals will fall for Level III.  With their unique martinis, excellent food and calming ambiance, Level III is the perfect place to relax with your friends next to the fireplace drink in hand.  

During happy hour (4-7 PM Mon-Fri), they feature their 3 signatures cocktails, 3 red and 3 white wines and their appetizers for half-price.  Their HH menu includes kobe beef sliders, parmesan fries, handcut potato chips with blue cheese dip, and mac and cheese.  With their delicious "Shanghaied" organic lemongrass and ginger vodka martini and kobe sliders both priced at $6, the only thing you'll be splurging on are calories!
author: Kimberly J.

description:
We came here for brunch and had the all you can eat buffet and crispy french toast. The food was decent but nothing amazing. Plus, it was more expensive than other brunch places with better quality food. 

The food is average but I took off one star since brunch is overpriced.
author: Lisa H.

description: We had breakfast there this morning as we are staying at the hotel.  I was served a tasty, large bowl of oatmeal, my husband did not like his pancakes.  He said it tasted like they were made hours ago and kept under a warmer.
author: Ali B.

description:
Please don't eat here. Save your money for a slice at Blondie's. I guarantee you that that will be infinitely more satisfying.

It seems like the marginally good reviews for Level III are thanks to their cocktails. But as for their food, please don't eat here. Especially for Dine About Town.

First off, it's disappointing when you don't get a choice of courses for a DAT menu. I know it's not a rule to do so or anything, but I happen to appreciate any restaurant that would give me a choice of food, seeing as how I'd be the one subjected to... *cough*... I mean, seeing as how I'd be the one eating it.

Second, flavoring your food is NOT a bad thing. Our three-course meal consisted of a half-decent tuna tartare (because as long as the fish is fresh, it's damn hard to screw up tartare), a god-awful butternut squash pasta, and some subpar ice cream sandwiches. The flavors were boring at best.
