The pasta was the single most disappointing plate of slop I've had in recent months. The butternut squash sauce and tagliatelle came out looking like gloopy mac n cheese. Not a high-end mac n cheese, mind you, but something that looks like it had a Velveeta label on it five minutes prior. 

Aside from being an ugly plate of food, it had no seasoning whatsoever. Butternut squash and cream. I think that was it. My friends and I looked around guiltily as we emptied the salt and pepper shakers onto our plates, because after all, when dining at a nice restaurant you shouldn't have to season your own food.

And then there were the ice cream sandwiches! A Neapolitan trio of chocolate, strawberry, and vanilla ice creams sandwiched between some cookies. The strawberry ice cream sandwich was plated next to some slices of strawberry. And you know what? The chefs at Level III cut their strawberries on the same cutting board as their onions. I know this because strawberries usually don't taste like onion! That was the end of the meal for me. Never mind that the service was decent, since we were one of only three tables in the restaurant at 12:30pm on a Saturday. 

Argh. Dine About Town, I want my $21.95 back.
author: Amy C.

description:
One star per level.  Sorry for those of you who read this earlier, but I was writing from my phone.

I stopped into this gorgeous, bright room for breakfast before working a university orientation across the street. The hostess table is a little hard to find, but the concierge was there to point the way. High ceilings, glass elevators and a blend of modern and classical deign elements make the room seem glamorous, despite the odd quadrant system. Servers still don't know the menu, but I'll wait until they are open a full day before I complain. 

The coffee is crap, the buffet looks great and my eggs benny were far from the best I've had in the city, but the eggs were cooked perfectly, even if the sauce was bland, generic and too thick. They're offered as full or half order, which was a nice touch and they came with limp yet tasty asparagus and a grilled tomato. It's fun to think that being here a half hour after they open for the first time, I probably ate the restaurant's first Benedict.
author: Quinn S.

description:
So I came back here for dinner last night. I was craving the mac & cheese that I had at the opening party so that's what I ordered--except instead of a tiny little taste of it...i had an entire plate...for dinner...all for moi!!! So far, I have to say...it's the best mac & cheese I've tasted. 

Also, I made a new discovery. This is a great place to go for a pre/post- theater dining. Not too many people know about it yet since it's fairly new and inside the JW so it won't be super crowded like Colibri or the Grand Cafe.
author: Sue L.

description:
ehhhhhhhhhhhh, I felt the food was alright. Kind of felt like they had the AC on...its freakin cold outside!! what are you thinking?!

Anyhow though, had this menu with an assortment of things, it was a set dinner with a salad or soup, entree and two desserts and a cheese..I think they over did the dessert portion, you dont need to give us chocolate and then a fondue and then a cheese platter. Way too much stuff, and I guess you were trying to cover up the fact your salad sucked.

The entree of beef two ways was pretty good and that could possibly be the highlight of the entire dinner. Service was good, she was very nice and i'm sorry I dont remember your name but keep up the good work~

Other than that, I would stick with the finger food instead of the dinner food...
author: phillip w.

description:
Take it to the next level?

Times when this question is ok to answer:
In an Ice Cream Shop

When picking out a piece of jewlery. Or Cake. 

NOT ok: 
When it is asked by that Creepy Guy at the end of the bar. You know the guy. No amount of beer is going to make him pretty. Get out of there Riding Hood!!

Also Ok:
Level lll.

I happened upon their menu, saw lobster mac on the brunch menu and set the date. That's all it too. Cheese. Macaroni. Lobster. 

The scene: Floor .... what, what floor could this possibly be on? hmmm...
Odd for brunch, I see gathering here as a first stop on a night on the town. Made for lounging with all the Ladies, or ditch those whiney bitches and get your Guys to go. TVs to keep their ADD riddled minds at ease and plenty for you to watch.

Sunday Brunch, however, is quiet. We were quite late for a brunch, but still we almost had the place to ourselves, which was fine, 'cause I broughts my appetite and I came to play. 

First Level: pastry basket instead of bread. Sweeeet.

Second Level: Drinks. Mine? Bloody Mary Baby, extra Bloody. Honestly, who knows what the fuck that means, but it sounded cool. 
I love a spicy kick-your-ass-Mary, and they have it so a Gal can customize here, so I chose the jalapeno-infused vodka with the kamikazi twist, includes ginger, wasabi and special spices. This was done RIGHT. Sure as shit better be, at $12.

Level 3: Brunch. Since the Lobster Mac was a given, I was having trouble deciding between the crabcake benedict or the chicken salad when I saw ratattoui. I am a sucker for eggplat, and so that's what was placed before me. Mama got the Cuba Cristo with spicy home fries and we settled in to our Mary's.
Food came out quick, lobster mac was first. I dug in with shame at a Level 0. Topped with toasted breadcrumbs, and creamy bechemel, this dish looked like a winner. LOOKED. I was disappointed in the flavor. Or lack of. I know that with seafood, you got to be subtle - but this had no soul. 
Ratattoui was better, I ate every last bite. Mama's Cristo was done on brioche, but the overall taste of all the dishes? A little canned. Kinda salty, kinda processed. 

I would go back for a take 2, but I'm going at night, wearing my ruby slippers and gettin me some more of that Mary! That's where the Levels are at - the BAR.
author: Katie W.

description:
Got off work and met up with a girlfriend the other day for cocktails. We decided to check out Level III at the JW Marriott. We walked into the hotel lookin kinda lost because all we saw were elevators and no signs indicating where Level III was. Well, duhhhhh.....we finally figured out that it was on the third level. How clever of them. Yeah, I can be the most blonde Filipino girl out there sometimes. 

The bar/lounge area was right off the lobby and not far from the hotel's front desk and so we really didn't feel like we were in a separate area. Although our table was perfect, it still felt like we were in the lobby. We decided to share the Seafood Salad, Kobe Beef Burgers and Tuna Tartare. It was delicious! They really designed their dishes for sharing and mingling over cocktails. The burgers and seafood salad came in threes. 3 mini kobe beef burgers and 3 small bowls of seafood salad. Everything tasted fresh and of good quality. I'll be back!
author: Anne E.

description:
I am seriously impressed by the food at Level III!

Located inside  the new JW Marriott, it's the hotel restaurant on the third level of the building - - hence, Level III.  One thing to note that the front desk is also on this level, and essentially, you are dining IN THE LOBBY.  It's a bit weird, but they've designed it in a way that works - - the lobby sort of melds right into the lounge, which melds right into the restaurant.... and while you may technically be eating your dinner in the "lobby" - - it's not bothersome.


While it is a hotel restaurant, it's not all that formal, and quite bright.  Service was excellent - - every server we encountered was trained to the JW Marriott style - friendly, pleasant, and polite.  

But the food was EXEMPLARY.
I am tempted to give it 5 stars because it was so good, but as I always say - - 5 stars is a class of its own, and while Level III really impresses me, the overall experience is not quite up to par.

Level III is a "shared plates" concept, tapas-like, if you will.  They do have larger entrees which could serve as your main course, but that, too, is best shared.  All "level 1" items are very small, all "level 2" items are a bit bigger, and all "level 3" items are similar to main entrees.

On this night, we started with the seafood salad, which was EXCELLENT.  I can't begin to explain how good this was, full of real lobster meat, clams, scallops and tons of flavor - - 5 stars hands down.  I could eat four plates of this by myself.  We also had the tuna tartare, and contrary to how bland it looked, with the green sauce, it was really quite good.  Then we had the Kobe Beef Sliders - - which were PERFECT.  We requested rare, and it came close... two patties with an onion ring inside the slider, it was perfect.  Last, but not least, was the Mac and Cheese w/ Black Truffles (the truffles are an added option, as is lobster mac and cheese).  At $17, this was one FANTASTIC mac and cheese, with Gruyere and mascarpone cheese.  The pasta itself was a bit overcooked for my taste, but it didn't take away from the final 5-stars I give this dish.  (Edited to add:  We also had ice cream sandwiches and freshly fried donuts with chocolate dipping sauce --  the sandwiches were excellent, piled high between cookies... the fresh donuts were good but I've had better.)

Combined with a bottle of J Pinot Gris, which was quite good, the total was a $135 or so and we were stuffed.  Frankly, for hotel dining, I thought this was quite reasonable.,,, and factoring in the food quality, I'd HIGHLY recommend Level III.

This is, without a doubt, a welcomed addition to the San Francisco dining scene, and with a little time, undoubtedly will become well-known for their great food and good service, at reasonable cost.  It's a fantastic date place, if you secure private booth seating - - or in my case, I preferred a table on the outskirts of the restaurant as it was quieter on this night.  Be it a date or a group outing, Level III can host your dinner, and I'd assume groups of up to 20 people could easily eat here.

Level III takes "shared plates"  to a whole new level, and does not disappoint!
author: Grace K.

description:
I like a good-looking restaurant, and I like all the hanging chandeliers and the plush booths at Level III, but the food here is, as many people say, overpriced and sub-par. And on top of that, the service is slow and inattentive. We'd made a reservation at 6 p.m., thinking that in any ordinary universe, two hours would be a perfect amount of time for a practically empty restaurant such as Level III to serve up a coursed meal, but because the wait staff was so inattentive, we ended up rushing to get our check taken care of by 7:30 so that we had enough time to walk to the theatre. 

When we first came in, there was no host at the host stand and had to wait. Then, once we were seated, it was 10 minutes before a waitress came by to take our drink order. And another 10 before she brought back our wine. Mind you, we were there at 6, and there were only two other seated tables in the whole place. We didn't get our first course until 6:40, at which point we told the head waiter that we needed to make an 8 p.m. curtain. At which point, they picked up the pace a bit, which was appreciated. 

I can barely even remember what I ate there, save to say that their French Onion soup is unmemorable and the butternut squash pasta had no subtlety (basically just tasted like butternut squash). My desserts were three little ice cream sandwiches, that I left unfinished because it was 7:40 and I had to get to the Orpheum.

Slow service plus uninspired food? Not a place I'm likely to return to.
author: Stevi C.

description:
A solitudinous dinner, I reasoned, would help assuage my mounting anxiety stemming from a depressingly long game theory problem set due next week. 

As I stepped out of the JW Marriott's third floor elevator, I noticed an unpeopled hotel lobby/dining room. With time, though, Ryan Jette, Level III's chef de cuisine and erstwhile French Laundry chef de partie, undid my unease with his enrapturing prix fixe menu menu. 

The amuse bouche was a chestnut soup with apple relish. Although a bit cloying for an amuse bouche, I savored the lingering roasted chestnut aroma.

In addition to the prix fixe, I ordered the sliders. Gruyere melted down onto the plate, the patties' interiors revealed a luminous rose color, and the crispy onion rings all harmoniously married.

Next, I had the tuna tartare. The chili powder, cayenne, ginger, and wasabi were pleasant additions to a ubiquitous dish.

The beef fillet au poivre with pommes frites and veal jus was a really good steak. The veal jus, which boasted a mostly salty flavor along with the slightest fruity note, inhibited the peppercorns from overwhelming the palate. The fries had an unforgettable crunch. The only conceivable way to improve them would have been to cook them in duck fat. For that, I suppose I will have to revisit Monsieur Mina.

The dessert was mundane - three bite-sized ice cream sandwiches.
author: Andrew F.

description:
A fun, trendy place that delivers!

The old Pan Pacific hotel has been remodeled to a luxury hotel that can compete with the best of them. Level III is a lounge/restaurant that offers full service whether or not you sit down in the lounge or eat at the restaurant. I was there for the grand opening and the menu was delightful comfort food -- mini sliders with onion rings, mac and cheese with truffle oil and shavings... fantastic. 

The space is designed in a contemporary and luxurious style -- it offers a mix of quiet corners that are more intimate --perfect for date night-- or open, loungey areas -- perfect for ladies night out. 

I got a chance to chat with the manager, Steven for a bit. Even though he's opened some hot spots in town - Tartine, Blowfish Sushi -- he's very warm and down to earth. I think I've found the next 'hot spot' in town.
author: lindsey l.

description:
Where do SoCal locals go to watch the Laker playoff's?  That's right --on the third floor of the JW Mariott in San Francisco. 

We initially thought, go to the closest spot to the hotel to catch the game.  By default since we were staying there we went to Level III and heck why not---it's happy hour from 4-7.  Perfect timing.  And amidst the hootin' and hollarin' and trash talking to the other guests that were rootin' for the chicken Nuggets, we did manage to stop and pay attention to the lush decor and the upscale appetizers that are far more swankier from the ESPN Zone.

Great for happy hour. Best mac n cheese you'll ever put in your mouth.  Don't believe me?  Oh you will when you try it and get a squirty surprise.

If it wasn't for all of our game chaos, this place seems like it would be a nice place to chill with friends.  The restroom experience is even posh-- listening to the sounds of jazz from Etta James to french, makes you feel shi-shi even while peeing. 

Level III, props to you guys for takin' in a bunch of rambunctious Laker fans.  LAAAAAKE SHOW!!!!
author: Sharen G.

description:
IF you are looking for a public place to practice your art of seduction, look no further. Level III at the JW Marriott is the place to win his (or her) heart (or body).

Level III Restaurant has city views in a quiet corner for that tête-à-tête which is perfect for wining and dining 
(for more discreet setting, they also have intimate dinner booths)

The Service is not obsrusive but very attuned to your needs which in turn, makes you focus on your date's needs

Decent wine at a great price ($20 is the lowest -- at that price, you can use the extra savings on the sensual dessert -- try the trio of ice cream sandwiches)

kobe sliders (3 to a plate and so yummilicious)
mac n cheese with truffle oil (decadent)
tempura veggies -- (made you feel that it was actually healthy even though it was fried)

The fact that this restaurant resides in a hotel works in your favor -- you can start your seduction in restaurant then work your way to your room. 

Bon Appetit!
author: Vanessa J.

description:
Okay, I think it is really annoying when I am really the first to review, but someone else, who has just heard of somewhere new, or happens to know the owners whatever, takes the blue ribbon away! 

But, this place Level Three. After a few hours of shopping, I could tell I was being led towards a watering hole. From previous experience, I knew it would be a place that served Martinis. It was. 

Level three was actually having their premier opening party on this particular day, and there were lots of vendors, fire dancers, passed aps, and champagne, and wine. Dry ice rose out of the fountain, and it was very pretty. 

The bartender seemed a little dazed, and I was surprised they let us order the food, that minutes later was being passed around free at the party. Thanks for the heads up dude. 

The decor was great, some neat couches, and a great place to hang out if you were staying at the hotel, as there are tons of places that you can hook your laptop up to.
author: Danielle V.

description:
Update: Feb 2009
Happy Hour here rocks! Three white wines, three red wines, three cocktails and appetizers half off. We stuffed ourselves on mac and cheese and sliders and guzzled Shanghaied cocktails like no tomorrow. Awesome!

---------- 

Monday nights aren't usually the best night for getting a good feel for a restaurant. Since they are new, I'm giving the server a pass on forgetting one of our dishes, for mis-understanding our requests a couple of times and mixing up which sliders were medium-rare and which were medium-well. 

That being said, I like the decor, though it would be nice if the lights weren't SO bright. We had a decent sized group so we were able to try a few dishes. The sliders were very good, along with the black truffle mac and cheese! We tried most of the "level I" dishes and all were tasty. 

The cocktail list isn't as extensive as some other places, but the ones we did have were unique and well made. Nice wine list overall, though the mark-up on bottles is fairly high (even for SF). 

Nice experience even though our server could have used a bit more training. We'll try again, for sure!
author: Sarcastic T.

description:
Found Level III via Yelp and Opentable about 6pm on a Saturday night.  All the usual, "hot", places were already booked, but I figured I'd try something new.

Decor - definitely a bit bright, music too soft.  Hotel-ish, (it is in one).
Crowd - sparse.
Level 1 - Cross-cut chips w/blue cheese.  Great.  Of course, we're lovers of blue cheese anything.
Level 2 - Vegetable and shrimp tempura.  Very tasty.  Sauce was unique.
Level 3 - Mac n Cheese.  Excellent.  We both loved it.
Level 3 - King Salmon - Kind of bland.  It was mixed with sea grass, a few different tomatoes and a broth.  The tomatoes were very yummy.
Level 3 - Tuna.  She loved it  I'm not a fan of raw tuna, so I'm not gonna comment.

Overall, we loved the food, but the place is just too quiet for a Saturday night.  It worked out well though for our date. :)
author: shawn p.

description:
A few of my friends and I made our way to Level III a few months ago.  I really liked the space/vibe, but since the place was still rather new, it was shall we say...rather empty as well.

The restaurant itself opens up to the rest of the hotel floor and bar.  Which was nice I guess.  You can see the comings and goings of the guests etc. etc.

Food wasn't outstanding, but it was tasty and we did enjoy it.  Among the items we ordered, were mac & cheese, bistro fries with parmesan and parsley, American Kobe beef sliders, and oysters on the half shell.  I know there were a few other things ordered but I can't remember.

I'd definitely come back and give this place another go.  Hopefully by this time word  has spread around thereby bringing them some more business.
author: Jennifer H.

description:
** My fiance informed me the tip was returned right away! It still happened but Thank you for fixing it right away... 5 stars for Level III!


Went to dinner on Christmas (Back up I go through spurts when writing reviews...) Anyway, Went to dinner on Christmas and had a fairly good time with my fiance. The food was tasty, but took a long time to make it to the table. The waiter was kind enough to notice so he comped the drinks. Because of the holiday I won't be mean, and I am actually glad they were open because it gave us a pleasant evening out of the house together. My only gripe was that we left a VERY nice tip in cash at the table and they still charged a tip on the cc... NOT COOL LEVEL III
author: Miguel V.

description:
Came here for an anniversary dinner with my g/f.  We both got the prix fixe and paired it with wine.  We were really happy with everything we ate except the over exaggerated pepper on our filet mignon.  Way too overpowering... once we scrapped the pepper off, it was great tho.  We got the tuna tartar, filet mignon, cheese and panna cotta for dessert.  

As for the service, our waiter was attentive and well mannered.  Four stars for this place.
author: Dalia A.

description:
You know there's something about you, baby so right...

Ok wait that's Level 42. Level whatever, this is the theme song you feel when you step out of the space-age elevator and walk into the swank Level III lounge. 

I couldn't live you without you , baby tonight. 

The food was very good, my bouche was amused and all following courses: salad with pancetta , salmon with spinach, and trio of mini ice cream sandwiches, were tasty and paired well with wine.  Presentation and service were top notch. I'll be back soon, perhaps to try the happy hour menu after a hard day of work or shopping!

Something about you, the way you are so right...
author: Sarah B.

description:
Came here for the first time with a group. Actually I was meeting them here. So I came in a little after 6 because of traffic and didn't know this place had food during happy hour. I had wondered why the place was kind of empty for such a beautifully designed room. So I went to the bar after saying hi to everyone.

I ordered my cocktail and that glass came out to be $14.00.  I talked to one of my friends and even he said his shot which was $5 at happy more than doubled afterward. Now I know why the place was empty.
author: M C.

description:
When you walk in the door, of course you are entering through the hotel; but it smells so good! 
You can take the "Willy Wonka" style elevator up to the third level which is the restaurant. The interior is very uniquely decorated and the seating is very comfortable. 
The menu is on the small side but they offer some great snack type options if you just want to have a few drinks and a small "bite".
Might I suggest the nut tray- they have an outstanding selection of nuts and the presentation is really neat.
I would surely go there again!
author: Janell D.

description:
Three things to note about this place. Food, service, and set up. It's in a hotel lobby. All be it a very nice hotel lobby, it's still not like you're in a restaurant as much as in a lobby. Service was pretty sub par. And by service I mean our waitress. We brought a bottle, which she spilled on my menu, and cleared away before we had completely finished it. Had we not been late for a play those would have been fighting words. 

The food however was worth every bit of anything we had to put up with. I was stunned with how good it actually was. We had the short ribs and the Salmon lobster plate. 

I recommend against desert though. It was big enough for a pixie and not for an adult.
author: Casey C.

description:
Surprising!

I went here for an early dinner Sunday with a small group, so it was pretty quiet but hopefully that was based on the day of the week. 

We all enjoyed the multiple appetizers we ordered- mac & cheese, fries, sliders, ahi tuna, tempura. 

Service was also very friendly and our food came out quickly... however our cocktails took a v-e-r-y long time, so long that even our non-cocktail drinkers were wondering what was going on.

That was weird. 

Overall all, though, I did enjoy my experience. I might try it again on a Thursday nite, for HH!
author: Nenette Y.

description:
I made a reservation here for my birthday dinner on a Friday night because it was one of the few restaurants that still had tables available on OpenTable by Wednesday. Normally, this would be a big warning sign, but I had always heard mixed reviews about this place, so I didn't give it much thought since I had been wanting to try it for some time. 

We arrived a little late for our reservation, but it was no problem because the place was so empty you could've heard crickets chirping. Besides one other group of people a few tables away, we were the only diners in the restaurant. 

Despite the lack of patrons, I really liked Level III. They have a $39 prix fixe menu that has many nice choices from the menu that add up to well over the price of the prix fixe. I ordered seared scallops, filet mignon, and a fruit filled creme brulee. The scallops were a little lukewarm, but cooked just right. The filet mignon was super soft and tender. And finally, the creme brulee was to die for (I don't even really like creme brulee). I also had some of my bf's new york steak, which made me regret my filet mignon. His steak was so juicy and melt in your mouth I totally foodgasmed. 

I think this place is a little underrated. The general complaints I've heard from people is that it's expensive and the food isn't that great, but I think if you go with the prix fixe menu, it's not really more pricey than many of the other nicer restaurants out there. The food is pretty good too; no complaints here. If you need a last minute reservation at a nice restaurant because you failed to think ahead, this is a great option.
author: Danny L.

description: The food was reasonable and the atmosphere was right up my alley - calm, casual, private and chill. But the service was so horrible, it takes away 2 of the 3 stars the food deserves.  Our waitress forgot our drinks, then after remembering 20 minutes later, had to give us the bar menu again because she accidentally gave us yesterdays bar menu.  Whatever, things happen... so we order new drinks, which take a good 20 more minutes to come out.  We order our food and the wrong thing is served... I dont let the waitress know because she's having a bad day is my guess.  I wanted another drink, but she was nowhere to be found.  Ok fine, don't take our money, but then it took 30 FULL minutes to get our bill.  Completely ridiculous.  It was honestly like anytime this lady came over to deal with us, she immediately went to take a dump right after.  Totally lame as we had high hopes.  The food was ok and the drink menu was pretty awesome (backlit ipad-ish type menu), but that's as good as this place gets.
author: Trey W.

description:
I would say 4.5 stars.  The food is very tasty - every bite and every dish has great flavor and imagination.

the restaurant is in the lobby and I wish they would have closed it off in a separate room from the lobby,..

Servers must be new as they were a bit inexperienced and seasoned...but for a hotel restaunrant what should I expect?  Well what about Minna that is in a hotel.  Americano or Cuba de SF or Cortez.

In any case- great times, great food, and great company was a fabulous night....
author: Rob C.

description: My hubby and I loved our dinner the food was amazing however one of our waiters was just ok  he seamed put out by helping us and gave my husband the wrong change back on our bill. But on the up side we did have a really great waiter that sat us for dinner and helped through our meal he was exactly the kind of guy you want to serve you at a place like level III ask for Joseph he was amazing!
author: Jayme E.

description:
I would call the service bad here, but I'm not sure we actually had any service.  Sheesh.  This place will fail, and very soon, if they don't get their act together on the service front.  It is an absolute failure.  

Menu was limited though relatively interesting. Food was prepared reasonably well, but was nothing special in my experience (especially given the price point). 

Drinks were insultingly over-priced, and the tonic in my G & T was flat.  Nice going guys. Why is it always that the super-expensive drinks are the absolute worst prepared?  

Went on a Wed at 8pm, there were only 2 other tables dining. Despite this nearly empty restaurant, the service was extremely slow, inattentive, and disinterested. We stood at the empty podium for 5 full minutes before someone appeared from the back to grudgingly take us to our table, with no apology. In fact, they tried to walk right past us until we spoke up.  They made no attempt to explain the menu or offerings (even when asked), or make us feel welcome. Seemed like they should have been working in a crappy diner somewhere, instead of a nicer restaurant. Truly inept on every level; maybe the manager went home early that night because it was so empty.  If they keep it up, they can all stay home when this place goes under.
author: Artie D.

description:
Some girlfriends and I went here for happy hour.   My friends had a couple of their happy hour drinks and didn't like them, they were "disgusting".  We had garlic fries as an appetizer (yummy!).  

The place is nicely decorated, a comfortable place to chitchat.
author: Phuong H.

description: Yummy crunchy French toast, great espresso, and fantastic service!  Would come again most definitely!
author: Janet Y.

description: I had read about the renovation of Level III and by the looks of the pictures and the articles I was very curious to check it out.  I must say that the review was much nicer to it than I am.  It did look nice inside but honestly wasn't anything more than a glorified hotel bar.  We had a bunch of appetizers that were very good but nothing to write home about.  Happy Hour was a good deal for the appetizers and it was a perfect location for us since we were seeing a play but I wouldn't go out of my way to go here again.
author: Blake B.

description:
The restaurant is located on the 3rd floor/level of the Marriott resort. The decor was very nicely put together. Very modern, and if you're lucky enough for one of their booths, very private. It wasn't too crowded for a Friday night, but maybe it's the economy.. who knows... We were seated promptly, but.. that didn't mean we were noticed promptly. We probably sat there for about 20 minutes before our server came around with water. Then waited a few more minutes to receive the additional drinks we ordered. But that was the last problem we had as she became very attentive for the rest of the night. 

I started with the Lobster Bisque, and my boyfriend ordered the French Onion Soup. Both VERY delicious. The French Onion soup was not too salty, and perfectly cheesy. And the lobster bisque was creamy. For our entree, I had the King Salmon Sautéed Spinach, Glazed Pearl Onions and a Tarragon Buerre Blanc  and he had the New York Steak with Roasted Chestnuts, Haricot Verts and Truffle Veal Jus. The new york steak was awesome!! very delicious and tender. the salmon was very nicely cooked and flaky, but wasn't as tasty as i had hoped it to be. For dessert, we had the ice cream sandwich.. YUM!!! oh man, little pieces of heaven. I wanted to order a dessert wine but didn't know what would go great with the 3 cheese platter we had, our server brought back a delicious Gewurztraminer (but didn't get the name), and also brought a pretty big tasting of a port she likes (no charge). Very nice gesture on her part.

Parking is non-existent around here, but, what can you expect with the neighborhood.
author: My C.

description:
Came here for lunch with my best friend after reading the reviews. The food was delish! The tables we sat at were comfy & cute. 

It's also a good place for meeting clients and business associates.
author: T G.

description:
Cool place in the heart of downtown for a Happy Hour bite to eat.  The mac n cheese, kobe beef sliders and seasoned fries were tasty, but I can't weigh in about the other items on the menu, though they looked yummy in theory. 

Whimsical drink list too.  Yummy caiparenia's.  The waitresses my party encountered were sweet but the place was pretty dead so yeah.  Drinks are about the price of most bars of this ilk in this area so be prepared to live with that.

The decor I could take or leave.  Seems like it lacks longevity but maybe I'm wrong since only time and consistently good food and service will tell.  Overall a cool place to grab a stiff drink and share some mac n cheese with friends after a ball busting day at work (4pm - 7pm M-F).  And pretend you're living Sex and the City or some madness.
author: Margaret L.

description:
Overpriced food and wine list - even more so for a Marriott. Service not bad but why does the waitress have to kneel on everyone's booth (seat) to take the order? I don't even see that at Denny's. Some diners dressed like slobs.

Ordered Filet Mignon and clearly specified 'medium rare', came out medium well. Glad I went but would never return on my dime.
author: Bobby J.

description:
Went for happy hour: 
Decor is great, food has generous portions, drinks and food were dirt cheap, service slow. 
But where is everybody it is a huge space, with zero ambiance, an elevator music...that you barely hear...
author: Carpe D.

description: Great food! Everything we had was awesome... Pre-fix menu: scallops, filet, dark chocolate dessert. $39 Perfect atmosphere, service and food.
author: A M.

description:
FAIL.  
This bar seems to think because Bourbon & Branch can charge $15.00 for a drink, they can too. The decor is lovely, but  bar is much too large.  The small drinks taste like they were made with generic mixers picked up at Safeway.  It is a shame as they sounded wonderful.

As for the food, the portions were generous, but they were bland.  Had I paid full price for the Mac & Cheese, I would have been very annoyed.  

If you want to grab a drink away from the Union Square crowds, I'd consider this place, but stick to beer and skip the food.  Honestly, I think you can do better elsewhere, though.
author: She-Ra ..

description:
When we book this place for dinner we didn't know that it was in the Marriot.  Just a FYI like others has mentioned.  The restaurant is on the same floor as the lobby and it's open to the lobby.  I was expecting something more intimate, again just another FYI.

I tried the prix fixe menu paired with the wine.
I think we must have caught them on an off night because I think our waiter wasn't a waiter.  She was a bit challenged with English and wasn't familiar with the menu.  She was super courteous though.  Also there were only three other parties in the restaurant when we at (we had an early dinner) and the food too a VERY long time to arrive.
The scallops - they looks great on the dish but mine had some grit them!  The chorizo wasn't as tasty as I thought it was going to be either.
The fillet mignon looked great on the plate at it was tasty  Not the best but good.
The dessert the 'warm apple pie grunt' was good, we all loved it.
The wine pairing (for the price) was a good deal and to me matched the food pretty well.  Unfortunately the food took so long to arrive I had finished my wine before the food came.
The kids had the Mac and Cheese - and as others have said, it's very good.
So - for the price that I paid it was good.  Very good for a Marriot hotel (I eat in a lot of Marriot hotels).
author: R P.

description: The hotel is very nice, free valet parking because we were dining at Level III.  The food was casual but detailed.  The kobe sliders, lobster bisque, tuna tartare were all very good.  The chicken sticks and mediterranean mussels were mediocre.  It was very quite there, hardly anybody... In a way, it's nice because we felt very private.  The private booth table they gave us was great.  Overall it was a great experience.
author: Jay T.

description:
My friend was visiting and staying at the Marriott, so we decided to try Level III. Well, when I got out of the elevator, the restaurant was kind of hidden. The decor was not bad, quite bright and fun. The table was spacious and it felt comfortable. 

I ordered the prix fixe three-course dinner. I started with tuna tartar, which was right on and delicious. Then, my main course was absolutely fantastic. It was a white fish in a tomato broth. The flavor was subtle, and compliment the fish very appropriately. Then I finished with their cheese plate, which was also fantastic. The cheeses were served with grapes, pear slices, strawberries, dried fruits and nuts. It was a great way to finish dinner.
author: Jose K.

description:
I was here for dine about town this past year. I have to say the food was amazing! The three courses and wine pairings were spot on and and delicious. Our waitress was also very attentive and sweet. 

I started with the beet salad, followed by the filet mignon and ended it with a cheese plate for dessert. Everything just melted in your mouth.

Level III is a hotel restaurant which is not busy at all and the ambiance is not the best but it is warm with red decor and high ceilings.

I would have never guessed that the food was as amazing at it was. Totally underrated....definitely recommend this place.
author: Kalifornia S.

description:
I went to Level III with my Bf as a guests of Nirvino Mixology Contest. We ordered several appetizers and it was really good.  If you don't know what to order, try some of these foods:

1. Mussels  ( Can't miss It! )
2. Mac n Cheese ( Simple but the taste was standing out! )
3. Tuna Tartare ( Even it came in the small portion but it was gooddd!)
4. Gin Gin Mule ( It's easy to drink, good start of the night )
author: Sasitorn O.

description:
Went here for a V-day dinner w/ some ladies.  The food was pretty good.. I particularly enjoyed the Kobe sliders, fancy mac & cheese, and fish tacos.  Less mentionable--the squash pasta.  Just tasted like squash, not much else.  I had a pretty good drink.. I think it was called Sunset Over Dunnagan or something like that?  Tasted like grapefruit wine.. yum.  Also kind of cool, the manager came out and brought us a round of fruity pink shots (which I didn't drink).. it was a nice gesture.

The cons.. it's kind of a weird space.  Very hard to tell where the lobby ends and restaurant begins.  Had a hard time finding the hostess to seat us.  And they definitely jacked up the prices for Valentines day (booo lame fake holiday), thankfully the manager let us order off the regular menu and not the prefixed $70 menu (ugh!)  Our server was kind of.. awkward.  Left dirty dishes piled up next to us after she gave us the bill (which was before we got our last drinks).  I'll go easy on her though, must not be easy serving lovey-dovey couples on vday.

Bottom line-- the food was great but pretty expensive.  The deco/ambiance is a novelty that wears off.  Service was ehn.  Probably wouldn't come back, but it was fun to try.
author: Christie C.

description:
Fantastic opening party - very, um, colorful!

Have been back for drinks and bar noshes.  One word. YUM!  Cocktail waitress was very attentive, but not over the top.  Beverages were perfectly prepared... even the gin martini I ordered accidentally. (I forget my friend will swap between gin nights and vodka nights, so when i pointed to her glass and asked for "one of those, but a bit dirty"... i got a dirty gin martini.... for someone that does not like gin, that was not the best move...!) I digress.  The food was great - can't wait to go back for a real meal.. The truffle (aka crack) mac and cheese was wonderfully decadent.  Chicken stix, mixed nuts, steak au poivre, can't even remember what all we tried. All great!
author: Danielle R.

description:
The third floor of the hotel includes this Level III restaurant, the bar, the lounge and reception. A bit confusing but the decor is fabulous. 

We sat at the high back booth and it was a quiet night, they've only been opened for about a month and I guess the word hasn't been out yet. 

Drinks a little on the expensive side $12- $15 but they are nice and strong. 

We've ordered the veggie tempura, Mac N Cheese & Kobe sliders. The Yuzu soy sauce that came with the tempura is amazing....I put some on my MacNChesse.

The MacNChesse was a little bland for my taste but you can tell it was made fresh. $ 9 plain, $15 with Lobster or $17 with black truffle. 

Kobe sliders were wonderful, it comes in 3 and the meat was lean & juicy. I wish it came with different sauce though....

Dessert we had Donut bites and it has this amazing mini Churro.....and it MELTS in your mouth. The dount balls are only soso but they give you warm chocolate sauce to dip in. If you are a churro fan...you've gotta try this. 

Overall I think it's a good deal consider the location & ambiance. Real relaxing and service is very prompt and friendly. 

Definitely way better than most hotel restaurants!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
author: Maggie C.

description:
i would have given it 5 stars, but the service sucked. the waitress was really stupid. came here with a bunch of girls and we ordered a lot of stuff and she couldn't remember a lot of what we ordered. can't u just write it down? simple as that. then she still forgot one of are orders and acted surprise, like we didn't order it in the first place. also we ordrered crab sandwhiches, but gave us pull pork instead. when we told her, she was like "oh no, the kitchen messed it up," but when we got the check it said "pull pork" can't u just admit u were wrong and say sorry. she was nice, but just stupid... also they gave us bread when all the food came out. aren't u suppose to give it in the beginning? luckily the food was really good or else....n e ways back to the food

the scallops were the first dish that came out and that was really yummy with a lil bit of bacon, the tuna tataki was my fav. never had anything like it with a lil bit of avacado and tanderines. the flavor is so good that i can't even describe it. the mac and cheese was light and so delicious. it comes out in a big pot. the dish is huge. the fries were cispy enough, the short ribs was super tender, the crab cake mini sandwhiches were also another favorite. crunchy and a lot of crab meat, flat bread artichoke was great, but the desserts sucked. also the place is inside jw marriott. it looks like a lounge more than a resturant, but super spacious and very cute. would come back here just for food, but hope they have smarter waiters.
author: Karen H.

description:
We were staying at the JW and decided to try the restaurant since we were too tired to go elsewhere....GREAT CALL!!!  The set up is kind of ackward....whenever I was in the lobby I couldn't tell if it was a restaurant or lounge or what?!  An open space "no boundaries" type concept.  Yes there were crickets chirping and no creatures a-stirrin' i.e. lots of empty tables, but what the hey...don't knock it til you try it.

FOOD HIGHLIGHTS:  Manila claims with bacon and bread crumbs-you only get 6 :(   Steak and fries - steak and fries were amazing, ahi tuna/poke...drinks are great too...I had 2 of the one with absinthe and passed out when I got to the room.   According to the waiter, the chef was trained/came over from the French Laundry to help them set up the menu and such.

LOWLIGHTS:  The mac & cheese, it was lukewarm, runny...there are so many great alternatives, stay away from the heavy starch, your tastebuds will thank you!  Oddly enough the chef's amuse bouche was gross....crab roe with lump crab meat and applesauce...Mott's must've been on sale somewhere.  

The manila clams were so awesome....just a dusting of bread crumbs and enough bacon to add to the flavor and a wonderful coconut milk sauce over that.  The combination of flavors and proportion of ingredients were perfect.
author: Rafa D.

description:
I found Level III on Opentable.com.  My girlfriends and I like to try new places and this was perfect before we went to a show last Wednesday.

Our bartender, John, was absolutely wonderful.  I asked if the Shanghai drink special was worth $15.00 and he informed me it was happy hour, so it was half price.  It was delicious, so I had two....worth the $7.50 any day of the week.  I have no problem paying $7.50 - $9.00 for a really good cocktail but would have trouble paying the full $15.00 price. 

I did have one issue with the bar itself.  I was moving my drink out of the way so as not to knock it over.  There is a flush light fixture that runs the length of the bar, built inside the bar itself.  Well, when I went to slide my drink out of the way it got caught on the lens of  the fixture (I guess it's not really flush at all when you think about it).  I ended up spilling some of my drink which I wasn't very pleased about.  It wasn't a lot, but enough where I needed a couple of napkins.

Our server, Jess (short for Jessica I think - but after two Shanghai drink specials I asked if we could call her Jess and she was more than happy to oblige) was equally friendly, very pleasant and down to earth.  She got us exact directions to the SF Playhouse, none of us had a clue to where it was.  

As Tasha said, the ham and cheese and sliders were yummy, as well as the tempura veggies with dipping sauce.  None of us were that impressed with the chicken salad, it lacked flavor.

I loved the decor and the open feeling to the place.

I will definitely go back when we're not so rushed.  I could have stayed longer but we were  rushing to make our 8:00 show time.
author: Judy B.

description:
Great food with great services!! Love the steak and scallop!
We are very greatful to have Michelle to give us the BEST friendly service!! We will sure go back!
author: Jenny D.

description: This restaurant is inside the JW Marriott and 2 blocks away from union square,  I have two things I want to say about this place, Kobe burger and fries.  When I first walked in, I did not quite understand the setup and it was bit confusing, one side is lounge and the other is dining.  I instantly feel in love with the decor and then a very attractive waitress appeared and said we can sit anywhere we like.  My hubby was in a mood for a burger, he ordered it medium well, and we split it,  The meat was fresh and perfectly cooked, the bread was a Kaiser roll, sauteed onions, sharp Cheddar and when I bite into it it was dreamy--and I am NOT even a burger girl.   At approx 15 dollars a plate, it is a bit pricey but sometimes you have to treat yourself.
author: Violeta H.

description: Very good food, and good service, but eerily empty on Labor Day for dinner.  I am a big fan of JWs in general, but this one was kind of a disappointment.
author: Jonathon S.

description: This place is great to have a meeting with a group of friends. I noticed several cocktail events going on while I was in the back with a book meetup. We all ordered beer and few of us ordered food. The fries looked deliciously seasoned, but the topper of the night was the chicken quesadilla. It was over flowing with goodies! The waitress was great. She never forgot about us which I was surprised she didn't because of the large cocktail party going on and us being the only ones hidden in the back of the restaurant. We will definitely be back for the next book meetup.
author: Casi C.

description:
Came here with Todd and Nikki. It was good, but not remarkable. 

We took the elevator up a few floors and found ourselves both in the lobby and in the restaurant. It is really blended with the giant hotel lobby, which was sort of strange. Happily, our table was behind some sort of mini-wall, so it wasn't agoraphobia-inducing. It was a Thursday night at 7pm, and the restaurant was nearly empty. Presumably this was because it's brand new, but it was a little weird, but also nice.

Our waiter was good, friendly and funny. He obviously had some time on our hands, and was very interested in our reaction to everything. Good stuff.

The food was good. We got the potato chips (called crisps or something like that) with an amazingly rich blue cheese dipping sauce. It was hard to believe how they got so much flavor into this sauce. We shared truffle mac'n'cheese, lobster mac'n'cheese, chicken stix (chicken on a skewer with peanut sauce), and little mini burgers. It was all quite tasty, but none of it knocked my socks off. Which was fine, because that would have been awkward. 

Anyway, I enjoyed it, but with so many awesome restaurants in SF, it's hard to give it a higher rating. Maybe I'll try it again in a few weeks and adjust my review.
author: Josh O.

description:
Highly disappointing, especially with so many other great restaurants around.  

Everything was on the heavy side: buttery, creamy, and / or fried.  While i'm a fan of all those things, just not for every dish.  The drinks were inventive, but the tastes weren't.  Lots of good ingredients, but mixed completely wrong.  

Made me think that the sub staff was on that night, but it was a Saturday night at 8pm, and the place was empty.
author: m k.

description:
I had been to Level III for their opening night party a few months ago and decided to stop back in again to show my boyfriend.  It was Thanksgiving weekend and we were giving THANKS that we didn't have any crazy plans with travel or family and stopped in to see what Level III had going on.  We sat front and center at the bar and had the perfect set up with a flat-screen TV playing that day's football game and one of the BEST bartenders I've found in this city for a long time..Jon. 

Jon was awesome!  He was super attentive and provided the perfect balance of checking up on us while giving us our privacy as well.  We ordered the kobe beef sliders (amazingly yummy) and I enjoyed 2 generous glasses of champagne while my boyfriend tried a few of the beers on tap.  Hour 1 led to hour 2 and we decided to stay for an entire meal and more libations.  We were not disappointed.

The service was exceptional and the food and drinks were very good.  We will definitely be back to visit Jon again and to take in the modern approach that Level III plays on the otherwise typical hotel lounge.  Private flat-screens, a roaring fireplace, an interesting and diverse wine list and a hip, fun menu!
author: Tiffany S.

description: All i can say, is the Mac and Cheese is BOMB!!! The rest of our meal was good too. :)  Service was great and our waiter also gave us tips on some cool spots to hit up.  If i ever get the chance to eat here again i will!
author: Erica O.

description:
Went there for lunch on a Sunday afternoon with 5 people. 

Food: 

- bistro fries are ok 
- selection was not great
- little pricey but it's a hotel, what can you expect? 
- club sandwich was uninspired, Kobe beef sliders were cooked pretty well though 

Service: 

I docked stars from my review because the service was so freakin' bad. We were the only customers in the restaurant for most of our meal (one other small group of 3 people showed up halfway through) and the waiter was completely incompetent. Not sure if he was filling in, but he brought out bread way too late. Only brought 3 bread plates for 5 people (then finally came out with 2 more when he realized his mistake). Was opening my coke and pouring it into a glass--he missed the glass and poured it into my water glass. Didn't replace it with a new water. Had to ask him 30 minutes later when he finally came around again to check on us.  No spoon or plate brought for tea and tea bag. Took forever to get the check, had to ask for it twice. 

You're supposedly a fancy restaurant in a hotel, but your service is so crappy. Lehm.
author: Ashlee T.

description:
Note to all brunch fans - if Level III is your destination, go by 11. You'd think they'd extend breakfast on the weekends till the afternoon, but that is not the case. We got there right after 11, and after putting our order in, the waiter came back to say they were no longer serving. We were going to leave, but after a bit of double checking, the waiter came back to tell us they'd go ahead and make our order. It was not a good start.

Fortunately, the food was excellent.  Since perusing their menu online, I had been obsessing about their French toast - wheat bread dipped in egg beaters, complemented by grilled cornflakes and fruit. Ah, yeah. It tastes as amazing as it sounds. And my friend had no complaints about his eggs benedict.

Further props for the good service, including letting me sneak a no charge taste of their house granola in the breakfast buffet. The only thing keeping this from five stars was the prices (bit steep) and decor (red carpets? tacky). I probably won't race back for dinner, but would definitely recommend Level III for brunch, er, breakfast.
author: Jason B.

description: Great setting, and the food was A-mazing! I have to say it's the best dining experience I had in San Fran. I had an incredible chicken dish (honey almond, I think) and it was melt-in-your-mouth delicious. Next time I'm in the bay area, I will definitely be visiting this place again.
author: Kellie W.

description: Social food. What an annoying choice of words to reiterate that small plates are conducive to sharing. I'd been keen on trying this place, so took my hawt (yet gimpy) date here before tonight's Sarah Silverman show. All-in-all, it was pretty good. The space could use more definition between hotel lobby versus restaurant, but is nicely appointed. We dug our private round booth, and both experienced "the Big O" upon tasting their Gruyere-laden lobster macaroni and cheese. While I wouldn't go out of my way to come back, I'd definitely do so if pimping in the area.
author: Gregor G.

description: Came here for Dine About Town.  Had the mixed green salad with berries and fresh vegetable with portebello ravioli.  It also came with a mini ice cream sandwich and coffee/tea.  It's a good bargain for $17.95.  Food was decent for the price but not spectacular.  They also had 2 hour validation valet parking so overall, good deal, but I would pick a different restaurant next time - not worth coming back a 2nd time.
author: Irene C.

description:
I thought that the relative hype about this place would leave it as a music-too-loud-people-everywhere bar/restaurant. I was very happy to learn that it was nicely laid out to provide privacy for people in the booths and also had no thumping music playing. Imagine being somewhere where you can actually hear your friends/date talk!

Went here for appetizers and drinks before dinner.  They have some of the best french fries ever!  The mixologist is very good and creative with drinks that work right and leave you wondering if you should order a second one or try something else.  I had the Golden Gate Fog and Shanghaied drinks, both which are excellent.  The waiter was attentive and gave us absolutely no pressure.  As we were only there for appetizers, I was almost sure he'd pressure us to order something from the main menu as we were there for an hour and a half. I was pleasantly surprised when he wasn't pushy that we had hardly ordered any food.  

We would definitely go back!
author: Kelley P.

description:
Hit or miss.  I can see how this place would be good for drinks and small plates, but for a dinner spot, there are better options.  
We brought a bunch of older (read: picky) ladies last week and were disappointed to see that they were ONLY serving from the Dine About Town menu--meaning picky old ladies did not like the limited options and immediately wanted to go elsewhere.  Thankfully, they allowed us to order off the general menu, which was greatly appreciated.  Our server was very perky and friendly and did her best to make everyone at the table happy.
Unfortunately, the food is inconsistent.  The lobster bisque was terrible--runny and watery with only bits of crab--where was the lobster?  The mac and cheese was good, but there were literally specks of lobster, no real chunks.  The sliders, however, were very good, although every order was prepared almost rare, despite a few order requested to be medium rare.  The potato crisps with blue cheese sauce were excellent, as were the tempura veggies.  
I could see myself returning after a day of shopping for a glass (or 3) of wine and some appetizers, but not really a go-to dinner place.
author: Jessica L.

description: Considering this place for a work function I am planning. The space has a cool but high energy feel to it. Great lounging furniture and decor for a cocktail reception...I'll update this review if we end up choosing the spot.
author: Cat T.

description: ...is just a ZERO.  There's a reason why this place was dead--uninspired drinks at high prices.  Decently portioned fries and skillet-sized mac&cheese at the happy hour price of $4, but they both needed a healthy dose of salt&pepper for flavor.  The space is just too big, bright and open.  Wouldnt go out of my way to come here.
author: brewgirl b.

description:
First off, don't get fooled by the stairs leading up to the round glassed off staircase that goes down.. it's not the entrance.  You actually have to go up to the 3rd floor / hotel lobby/registration to get to the restaurant.
The way that space is laid out, it's confusing as to where to find the hostess, but we found her.

We enjoyed the food but really can't say the same about the service.  With a restaurant that's located within a upscale hotel, we thought the service would be one of the selling point but we were thoroughly disappointed.
 
We made it there between there happy hour 5-7PM, and were glad to enjoy the half off cocktails and wines.  
Since we were there for the Dine about town, we tried their 3 course menu.  The steak was very tasty, the salmon was excellent with crispy crust but soft and moist.  The vegetables are great.  
We liked the lobster bisque, but we both thought the soup would be creamier than what was served.  Nonetheless it is still very delicious.

While we just got our desserts, our waitress put the bill on the table with the dollar sign up.  We were kinda of shocked.  Then as we went on taking a couple of bites, she came back and expected the bills to have been paid.  It took us at least another 10 mins to finish the 3 ice cream cakes, and it was just really odded that she rushed us through to pay the bill.  There were plenty of empty tables around us and we didn't ask for the bill so it really was rude for us to get that bill at the time it happened.

Then when we were ready to go, we couldn't find anyone to get us our coats.  Some staff member helped and then they have to hunt for our coats where eventually we were ready to leave.

I am not sure if I will be back anytime soon, as the regular menu looked pricey, and I am not impressed with the service at all.
author: Cynthia C.

description: I agree with the previous post here.  It is like Wille Wonka.  And the sad part about this is that its predecessor, the Pacific Grill, which was overpriced and bland in taste, looks better than this newly renovated cafe.   Nothing really appealed for me at lunch today.  I was hoping that the Chicken Salad and the French Onion Soup would wow me, but it was very bland.  They give you a good amount of chicken than the weeds that they serve on your plate.  Coffee Service was abysmal.  You call that service?  The server and busperson nearly ran into each other, and then the follies continue when he forgets to bring the half-and-half.  And the joint only had 3 or 4 tables during lunch.  They weren't busy at all.  I will stick with the places across the street from the this place.  JW Marriott is a big joke.  Too bad the Pan Pacific Hotel is gone.
author: Tony L.

description: Went there with a group of 8.  The service and ambiance was great.  Highly recommend the pan seared sea scallops and the salmon entree.  The pound cake dessert was only fair.
author: Ben L.

description: I came here for a Friday Happy Hour, and I really liked this venue. It's kind of hidden but it is a very large space with lots of seating areas and lots of standing room if you want to mingle with different people in a large group. I can't really comment on the drinks because I usually don't get alcoholic drinks but they did offer a HH specials menu. I tried my friends' mac and cheese and fries which were pretty good. We're already planning to return in a few weeks to host a pre-event for a fundraiser event.
author: Lisa M.

description:
what drew me to try out this place was the mac-n-cheese they had on the happy hour menu, b/c i love me some good mac-n-cheese

the friend and i ordered kobe beef sliders (which were just ok, not too special) + the salt and pepper fries (which were really yummy) + finally the mac-n-cheese (which kind of took a long time to come out, we honestly thought our server forgot to order it for us)...the mac was good, but was a little too creamy and i could definitely taste the gruyere

2 hours spent there + good catching up time + 2 glasses of wine/person + filling food came out to about $45, which was pretty good considering...but i dont think we'll have the desire to go back again
author: Alice K.

description: Just went for a Dine-About-Town lunch. Nice ambiance and good service. Chowder was delicious. Rib-eye and chicken were cooked just right. It was a good portion for $18 lunch.
author: Kar K.

description: Given the size of this space they'd have been better off putting in pool tables or air hockey.  What a waste.
author: Greg P.

description: Recently had dinner for a party of 13. The restaurant in general looks pretty current with the nice design and layout of furniture and tables. I thought it was a great spot for dinner.  The food was good and the wine was refreshing.  Enjoyed the company at dinner talking bout life and all that good stuff you talk about at dinner.  Overall it was a plus in my book, just marked it off my list of restaurants to check out.  As with any other reviews that you are reading, go out and try it yourself and see whats up.  Go get off that chair and stop spending your whole time on the computer, smile and enjoy your life.
author: marcus o.

description: I checked out this venue for a Nirvino event, so all my drinks were free. The happy hour prices looked fair, but other than that I wouldn't pay the prices they want to charge. The space is REALLY large and so has tendency to feel empty. I personally don't see it as a destination for locals, let's hope the tourists keep them busy.
author: Nikke G.

description:
happy hour bargain at it's best.

we're all trying to save money, but then again... I would also like to contribute to the economy and spend some money.  but it doesn't mean I need to spend the BIG bucks to have a good time.  okay, let's start this review:

pros / classy place, lots of room, good drinks, and great appetizers.  I just went for the happy hour prices and they're GREAT.  I had a 3 dollar beer and the 6 dollar kobe sliders... both a great deal if you ask me.  I wanted to try the mac and cheese... but I'll save that for next time.

cons / not much really.  it's around the union square area... and I work by the ballpark and live in the east bay.  but every once in a while, you need to get out of the box and explore.

sooo... support the economy and try to add this place for a new place to check out.
author: Walter M.

description: Came here for happy hour drinks and apps. First off, it is located in the lobby level of the JW Marriott hotel on Post Street, about a block from Union Square. Grab a seat by the windows and take a peek at the cocktail list and snack menu. Chicken sticks with peanut sauce, your typical Thai style satay. Sweet potato fries, a substantial portion, crisp, sweet, with your choice of seasoning (salt, pepper, garlic, parmesan, or all of the above.) Artichoke dip, featuring house made tortilla chips, which in my opinion was the star of the dish. The mixed nuts were a pleasant surprise, actually a tower of various nuts-smoked almonds, wasabi peas, cinnamon pecans, glazed cashews, and spicy peanuts.  The cocktails we tried: blueberry lemonade-blueberry vodka, fresh blueberries, not too sweet or sour, but very refreshing, pumpkin martini-fresh pumpkin puree, nutmeg, cinnamon, and vanilla vodka, sweet but not too, like pumpkin pie in a glass, blue cosmo-with blue curacao and white cranberry juice, was a little too sour. The downside of happy hour is the $5 drinks doesn't include the specialty cocktails, so we ended up paying full price for all of them. Still, it provided a good escape from the street for a nice afternoon buzz.
author: Coren D.

description: this place is awesome... the drinks during happy hour are the bomb and the view is great..... was here just last week for drinks on sunday night
author: Ronny O.

description:
This has become Brian and I's Sunday afternoon hang-out, lunch spot and sports bar. It's convenient to our house, and since they recently opened, they are doing their best to determine who their crowd is. The first Sunday we arrived to watch Euro Football 2008 and the bartender gave us a flight of all the red wines they had complimentary, so that we could determine what we liked, but alsowhat may or may not work behind the bar. 
As for food, we have enjoyed the Mac n' Cheese w/ black truffle oil (lovely!), the sliders (awesome!), Tempura (tasty!) and the French Onion Soup (delish!).
We enjoyed ourselves so much, we made it back the next 3 Sunday's to watch Euro games and eat and drink.
I have nothing to base my review on a weekend or happy hour, but for a cool non-pretentious hang out, with cool staff and strong drinks, this nails it perfectly. And this is a hotel lobby??? Yes, which makes the people watching just an added bonus!
author: Jason D.

description: Came here for the prix fixe menu on Valentine's Day. The waiter was wonderful- very knowledgeable, attentive, and sweet. The squash/walnut tortolloni was surprisingly one of the best things I have ever eaten. The halibut was a little dry, but everything else was good. The apple grunt desert was amazing.
author: F B.

description:
I will take into consideration with this review that this is a newly established restaurant:
My husband and I went here for dinner on Saturday night and were able to get a table next to the window right away (5).  The place is so bright with these huge chandeliers hanging down above the tables, I thought I was going to melt (2)!  The server noticed and came over right away to open the window for us (5).  Our server was very friendly throughout our entire meal (5).  They were out of the wine we ordered, so they upgrated for the same price (5).  We ordered the french onion soup (4 - smelly but tasty), the loster bisque (3 - very, very runny), tuna tartar (5 - yummy), macroni and cheese w/ lobster (4 - cheesy and tasty but not much of a lobster flavor), and ratitouille (3 - not very exciting).  The timing on the dishes was a little off, which I expect will get better with time.  The place is beautiful though and the colors incorporated in the chairs and carpet make it very nice.  The lighting, as said before, is a little too bright.  The servers were very friendly.  Maybe we will try it again in a little while when they aren't so new.
author: Rise G.

description:
the atmosphere is amazing! def worth getting a drink and checking it out.

the food was ok. i got the prie fixe and was not horribly impressed.  at $50, it wasn't horribly expensive.  the ginger jello thing was weird. they said it was a palette cleanser, but it was the 1st course. weird way to start a meal. nothing was worth going back for. not even the drinks.
author: Christopher L.

description: When to lunch here today and had a really yummy chicken sandwich on brioche.  So good.  Service was great, location was easy to get to when shopping down town and this is a place I will come back to.
author: Jaime A.

description: Was hoping the decor would be a bit less hotel lobby, but, as we were sitting in the hotel lobby, that would've been difficult. It was hard to find someone to seat us, but the host was very friendly once we found him. Service was a little spotty, but the food was great.
author: ike s.

description: 4.5 stars!  We went there on a Tuesday night around 7 and it was pretty empty. The dining room is beautiful and the round booths nice for dates. We had the waffle-cut potato crips (delicious), mac&cheese (mediocre), bisque (incredible and unique), and kobe sliders (my favorite).  Save room for the doughnut bites, and the ice cream sandwiches are worth trying as well. The service was attentive, and they do have some dessert wines - just ask.
author: Derek G.

description: For what they are charging, the drinks need to be A LOT better than they are.  For $15 a drink, I expect a bit more than an overly sweet concoction in martini glass. Additionally, the bar is far too large and is right outside the hotel registration desk. Atmosphere / ambience is definitely lacking. Would recommend passing this place by.
author: MO L.

description: This restaurant is Amazing! We eat here alot, the Chef is actually pretty famous. Was trained in Europe, try their Fixed Price menu. You will get a better deal. Their Fillet Mignon is the Best! It's located inside Mariott. You can get free Valet parking Validation if you eat at this restaurant. The view of the hotel interior is amazing, it's hollow in the middle. You have an amazing view going up and down the elevator. I highly recommend people to come and stay here. Definately 5 stars!
author: Michael W.

description: This lemongrass cocktail I chose was amazing! I have quite a bit of a sweet tooth so it was just perfect. After a few of those, we decided to have some food. The shrimp and vegetable tempuras were on point and perfectly seasoned. The batter stayed crispy and the miso-wasabi, and yuzu-soy dipping sauces were so tasty! Of course we couldn't skip dessert! we ordered the trio of ice cream sandwiches, and the cookies  and pairings with the flavorings complimented each other very well.  My favorite was the balsamic cookies with strawberry gelato. Service was great and attentive. Friendly people and comfortable decor. I usually enjoy a scene when it's a bit more lively but then again it is fairly new and I am sure this Level III is a hidden jewel soon to be discovered.
author: Laianna T.

description: A friend and I came here and each got different options on the Dine About Town menu, so we got to share one of everything between the two of us. The food was excellent! We both loved everything. Normally I think it would be a little overpriced, but the special fixed menu was a great deal.
author: Nicole V.

description: My husband and I came here several weeks ago and was a bit skeptical because of their hit or miss reviews. We decided to give it a try since it's fairly close to us. We came on a Sunday night and it was pretty dead and I was a bit worried. To our surprise, the food was actually pretty tasty and our waiter was very attentive & nice but the restaurant was practically empty so that might be the reason. I ordered the sliders which was good but not orgasmic. My husband ordered their pre-fix: pan seared sea scallops, ale braised beef short ribs, and for dessert I can't recall the name but I think it was a chocolate cake which we were so stuffed by that time we only picked at it. He enjoyed his entire meal and I think we'll swing by another time to check out their happy hour.
author: Xuyen H.

description: After having several change of plans to our Holiday Schedule last minute my fiance and I ended up in town, just the two of us for Christmas eve and Christmas Day. Having never been in the city, almost alone, on a Christmas we weren't really sure what to do with ourselves. We decided we'd get all dolled up and go out to a fabulous dinner at the Top of the Mark, Fairmont, or Ritz and  play fancy tourist in our own town I mean ya gotta check out these legendary SF locations sometime right? Well silly of us to think we could get reservations for any of these places on Christmas day for our fabulous dinner. We then turned to yelp and opentable to find out where we could eat. We live in Nob Hill so Level III was close. The reviews were only so-so so we went in with low expectations and were just happy they were able to get us in (plus we got open table points, always a plus for mystery place). The service, although clearly bear boned staff was excellent. They were totally full and only had about 2 people waiting so they were constantly rushing around, but very apologetic for any amount of wait and very friendly and informative about the menu. The menu wasn't anything amazing, but everything we had we liked. We each had a soup then shared a few small plates. i loved my french onion soup, his lobster bisque was a bit watery, but had a nice flavor. We had the mac n cheese with lobster which was rich(waaaay to heavy for my taste, but i don't like mac n cheese), some veal dish and oysters. Everything was good. I would go back for their happy hour deals if I went again. Overall they made our Christmas evening one to remember.
author: Audrey V.

description: I'm a bit torn with this review, and I'll try to explain why.  My friends and I decided to take advantage of Level III's dine about town menu last weekend before a big night out, and while the food didn't disappoint, the service left something to be desired.  Well, let me rephrase that - our waitress just plain old sucked.  Granted, I was the first of our party to arrive and was seated (by the manager himself), but the waitress ignored me for a good 15 minutes before the MANAGER (bless him) came and took my drink order.  Once the rest of my friends arrived, it went from bad to worse.  It took another 15 minutes for the girl to come around to take the rest of our drink orders, 30 minutes after that for her to decide to take our food orders, and then probably another half hour or more for our food to actually arrive.  In the meantime, the restaurant is still half empty, our glasses are empty, no one has come around to see if we wanted another round, and we are practically gnawing at our arms to ease our hunger pains.  All the tables around us somehow got bread, and yet no one has even offered us anything, despite us having been there for an hour at this point.  We had to flag down a busboy to beg for a basket of bread - at what restaurant do you have to ASK for bread??  Ok, so then we finally get our food - after another debacle where our waitress mistakenly brings us another table's order - and we pause for maybe 2 seconds in our ravenous eating to notice that the steak actually is pretty darn good.  At that point, we were ready to just leave and get on with our nights, but one of the girls decided to go voice our complaints to the manager, and he turned into recovery mode faster than a blink of an eye.  He practically ran to the bar and brought us 2 rounds of drinks, then proceeded to load us full of yummy desserts, including chocolate fondue and cheesecake, on top of our DAT desserts.  The waitress, however, was not apologetic at all and didn't even seem to care.  The manager was incredibly gracious and saved the night for us, and I would consider going back solely because of him.
author: Irene W.

description: No no no!  I went last night with a friend.  We're thinking hotel bar/restaurant (think Ame) where it will be cool vibe....well, let's just say there was NO vibe, because I think there were only two other people in the entire place.  It's a weird open space, and the reddish color everywhere just doesn't work.   So I'm figuring that because there's no one in the restaurant, the wait staff would be more attentive.  Well, the woman came over about 3 times in the first 30 seconds to ask if we wanted drinks, even though we told her we needed a couple of minutes to pick a bottle of wine.  Then later, when we wanted to get the hell out - no one was to be found.  The food was - eh.  The mac & cheese was okay, but nothing special.  The seafood salad was not good (gritty!), the salad was fairly boring, and the tuna tartare was good - but really hard to eat because it was in these miniscule pieces which were sprinkled along the plate (i.e. it looked nice, but wasn't very substantial).  Overall, nope - not going back there.
author: Leigh c.

description: I wish I could rate Level III higher as it is a nice venue. Today my friends and I did brunch and unfortunately a train of errors wrecked the experience. Firstly three of us at the table had to wait over 15 mins for our meals after the others were served. I ordered the crab cakes, and although the meal was tasty I expected crab cakeS, plural - not a single, small cake for $15. My friends also had to ask for their side servings that were supposed to come with their dishes. Plenty of room for improvement Level III.
author: Michael P.

description: From the red stemmed martini glasses to the hip Chilewich placemats they sure got the renovation right in this place.  The space is huge and very nice.  There's a fireplace in the lobby and lots of seating.  The decor is all in red & golds with lots of curtains, round booths and beautiful chandeliers.  The big rave though is for the food.  We stopped by for dinner pre Symphony. I had the pomegranate and asian pear mixed green salad and the veal croquettes on braised spinach with cremini mushrooms and truffle sauce.  Delicious!  My husband had the Hawaiian big eyed tuna appetizer (gorgeous presentation), and the lobster mac & cheese and his literally swooned.  We will definitely be back to check out their happy hour.  I'd call this one a hidden gem on Nob Hill.
author: Anne H.

description: don't let the aesthetic beauty fool you, we went in a group of four and only one of us enjoyed the food, which was fries, the chicken was the driest that ive had in a long time, mac and cheese had no flavor and the fish tacos were sub par at best, if you have one night in San francisco, don't waste it eating here
author: Kevin B.
